Week 1. Jan 6

countability of sets

notation. set operations

  • symmetric difference A△B:=(A−B)∪(B−A)=A∪B−A∩BA\triangle B:=(A-B)\cup(B-A)=A\cup B-A\cap BA△B:=(A−B)∪(B−A)=A∪B−A∩B
  • complement AC:=X−AA^C:=X-AAC:=X−A for A⊆XA\subseteq XA⊆X for univseral set XXX
  • cartesian product: A×B:={(a,b):a∈A,b∈B}A\times B:=\{(a,b):a\in A,b\in B\}A×B:={(a,b):a∈A,b∈B}
  • power set: P(A):=2A:={B:B⊆A}\mathcal{P}(A):=2^A:=\{B:B\subseteq A\}P(A):=2A:={B:B⊆A}
  • power of set: AB:={f∣f:B→A}A^B:=\{f|f:B\rightarrow A\}AB:={f∣f:B→A}
    • think about how subsets and function that maps element to {0,1} are same

notation. multisets: multiplicity matters.

notation. sequence sets: multiplicity and order matter.

defn. relations are subsets of cartesian products.

eg. in a graph G=(V,E)G=(V,E)G=(V,E), edges E⊆V2E\subseteq V^2E⊆V2 are relation.

defn. an order relation is set of pairs in a relation such that the first element is less than or equal to the second. it has

  • transitivity: if (x,y)∈R,(y,z)∈R(x,y)\in R,(y,z)\in R(x,y)∈R,(y,z)∈R, then (x,z)∈R(x,z)\in R(x,z)∈R
  • reflexivity: (x,x)∈R(x,x)\in R(x,x)∈R
  • linearity: ∀x∀y:(x,y)∈R∪(y,x)∈R\forall x\forall y:(x,y)\in R\cup(y,x)\in R∀x∀y:(x,y)∈R∪(y,x)∈R

defn. a function relation of f:A→Bf:A\rightarrow Bf:A→B is Rf⊆A×B={(x,f(x)):x∈A,f(x)∈B}R_f\subseteq A\times B=\{(x,f(x)):x\in A,f(x)\in B\}Rf​⊆A×B={(x,f(x)):x∈A,f(x)∈B}.

  • requirements of RRR to be a function relation:
    1. ∀x∈A ∃y∈B:(x,y)∈R\forall x\in A\,\exist y\in B:(x,y)\in R∀x∈A∃y∈B:(x,y)∈R
    2. ∀x∈A ∀y1,y2∈B\forall x\in A\,\forall y_1,y_2\in B∀x∈A∀y1​,y2​∈B, if (x,y1)∈A(x,y_1)\in A(x,y1​)∈A and (x,y2)∈A(x,y_2)\in A(x,y2​)∈A, then y1=y2y_1=y_2y1​=y2​

defn. a function f:A→Bf:A\rightarrow Bf:A→B is one-to-one if for all x1,x2∈Ax_1,x_2\in Ax1​,x2​∈A, x1≠x2x_1\neq x_2x1​=x2​ imples f(x1)≠f(x2)f(x_1)\neq f(x_2)f(x1​)=f(x2​).

defn. a function f:A→Bf:A\rightarrow Bf:A→B is onto BBB if for every y∈By\in By∈B there exists x∈Ax\in Ax∈A such that f(x)=yf(x)=yf(x)=y.

defn. an equivalent relation is a relation with

  • symmetry: if (x,y)∈R(x,y)\in R(x,y)∈R then (y,x)∈R(y,x)\in R(y,x)∈R
  • transitivity
  • reflexivity

defn. ∣A∣≤∣B∣|A|\leq|B|∣A∣≤∣B∣ if there exists a one-to-one function f:A→Bf:A\rightarrow Bf:A→B.

defn. ∣A∣=∣B∣|A|=|B|∣A∣=∣B∣ if any of following true

  • ∣A∣≤∣B∣|A|\leq|B|∣A∣≤∣B∣ and ∣B∣≤∣A∣|B|\leq|A|∣B∣≤∣A∣;
  • there exists f:A→Bf:A\rightarrow Bf:A→B that is both one-to-one and onto.

theorem. (Cantor–Bernstein) two definitions above are equivalent.

eg. let E={2m:m∈N}E=\{2m:m\in \mathbb{N}\}E={2m:m∈N}. then ∣E∣≤∣N∣|E|\leq|\mathbb{N}|∣E∣≤∣N∣ because we have f(m)=m2f(m)=\frac{m}{2}f(m)=2m​, and ∣N∣≤∣E∣|\mathbb{N}|\leq|E|∣N∣≤∣E∣ because we have f(m)=2mf(m)=2mf(m)=2m. so ∣E∣=∣N∣|E|=|\mathbb{N}|∣E∣=∣N∣.

eg. let A=(0,1)⊆R,B=[0,1]⊆RA=(0,1)\subseteq \mathbb{R},B=[0,1]\subseteq\mathbb{R}A=(0,1)⊆R,B=[0,1]⊆R. then ∣A∣⊆∣B∣|A|\subseteq|B|∣A∣⊆∣B∣ because we have f(x)=xf(x)=xf(x)=x, and ∣B∣≤∣A∣|B|\leq|A|∣B∣≤∣A∣ because we have f(x)=x2+14f(x)=\frac{x}{2}+\frac{1}{4}f(x)=2x​+41​ (shrink B to fit in A). so ∣A∣=∣B∣|A|=|B|∣A∣=∣B∣. but it is not obvious to find a both one-to-one and onto function.

eg. show ∣Z∣=∣N∣|\mathbb{Z}|=|\mathbb{N}|∣Z∣=∣N∣.
define g:Z→Ng:\mathbb{Z}\rightarrow\mathbb{N}g:Z→N

g(x)={2x, x≥0−2x+1, x<0g(x)=\begin{cases} 2x & \text{, } x\geq 0 \\ -2x+1 & \text{, } x<0 \end{cases} g(x)={2x−2x+1​, x≥0, x<0​

it is both one-to-one and onto. □\square□

examples of infinite sets of same cardinality:

  • E≈NE\approx\mathbb{N}E≈N

  • Z≈N\mathbb{Z}\approx\mathbb{N}Z≈N
  • R≈(0,1)\mathbb{R}\approx(0,1)R≈(0,1): use tan⁡:(−π2,π2)→R\tan:(-\frac{\pi}{2},\frac{\pi}{2})\rightarrow \mathbb{R}tan:(−2π​,2π​)→R function
  • any two real intervals are of same cardinality

theorem. (Cantor) N≈Z≈E≉(0,1)≈[0,1]≈R\mathbb{N}\approx\mathbb{Z}\approx E\not\approx (0,1)\approx[0,1]\approx\mathbb{R}N≈Z≈E≈(0,1)≈[0,1]≈R.
proof. show there does not exist an onto function from N\mathbb{N}N to (0,1)(0,1)(0,1) (or equivalently (0,1)(0,1)(0,1) to N\mathbb{N}N). let f:N→(0,1)f: \mathbb{N}\rightarrow(0,1)f:N→(0,1) be any function, write

choose the diagonal d=0.x00x11...xnn...d=0.x_0^0x_1^1...x_n^n...d=0.x00​x11​...xnn​..., and let rf=0.y0y1...ynr_f=0.y_0y_1...y_nrf​=0.y0​y1​...yn​ where for all iii we have yi≠xiiy_i\neq x_i^iyi​=xii​. we claim rfr_frf​ is not in the range of fff. so fff is not onto. □\square□

theorem. (generalized Cantor) for every set AAA, A≉2AA\not\approx 2^AA≈2A.
pf. let f:A→2Af:A\rightarrow2^Af:A→2A and we want to show it cannot be onto. define Zf={x∈A:x∉f(x)}⊆AZ_f=\{x\in A:x\notin f(x)\}\subseteq AZf​={x∈A:x∈/f(x)}⊆A, we have Zf∈2A,Z_f\in2^A,Zf​∈2A, we want to show for no x∈Ax\in Ax∈A we get f(x)=Zff(x)=Z_ff(x)=Zf​ (fff must miss this subset in 2A2^A2A). assume for contradiction that we have x0x_0x0​ such that f(x0)=Zff(x_0)=Z_ff(x0​)=Zf​, if x0∈Zfx_0\in Z_fx0​∈Zf​ then x0∉Zfx_0\notin Z_fx0​∈/Zf​, and vice versa... □\square□

Week 2. Jan 10

eg. show for all AAA we have A≤P(A)A\leq \mathcal{P}(A)A≤P(A).
define one-to-one mapping f(a)={a}∀a∈Af(a)=\{a\}\forall a\in Af(a)={a}∀a∈A. further by generalized Cantor we have A<P(A)A<\mathcal{P}(A)A<P(A). □\square□

eg. show R≈P(N)\mathbb{R}\approx\mathcal{P}(\mathbb{N})R≈P(N).
start by R≈(0,1)\mathbb{R}\approx(0,1)R≈(0,1). note we can use binary expansion to represent numbers in (0,1), eg 0.10110100... but for each number, this series of 0 and 1's will represent a subset of natural numbers if 1 represents chosen and 0 otherwise for i∈Ni\in\mathbb{N}i∈N-th digit. eg f(0.10101) = {0,2,4}. □\square□

corollary. ∣N∣<∣R∣|\mathbb{N}|<|\mathbb{R}|∣N∣<∣R∣.

puzzle. suppose we have A<P(A)<P(P(A))<...A<\mathcal{P}(A)<\mathcal{P}(\mathcal{P}(A))<...A<P(A)<P(P(A))<... what is the size of these sets altogether? the 'number' of sizes is larger than the 'size' of any set.

puzzle. is there any set AAA such that ∣N∣<∣A∣<∣R∣|\mathbb{N}|<|A|<|\mathbb{R}|∣N∣<∣A∣<∣R∣, ie size between that of N\mathbb{N}N and R\mathbb{R}R? there is no way to answer this question.

notation.

  • ℵ0=∣N∣\alef_0=|\mathbb{N}|ℵ0​=∣N∣
  • ℵ1=\alef_1=ℵ1​= next infinite set of size larger than ℵ0\alef_0ℵ0​
  • ℵ2=\alef_2=ℵ2​=...

defn. set of size ℵ0\alef_0ℵ0​ are called countable sets.

  • every infinite subset A⊆NA\subseteq\mathbb{N}A⊆N is countable.

defn. set of size greater than that of N\mathbb{N}N is uncountable.

theorem. (closure properties of family of countable sets)

  1. if A,BA,BA,B are both countable, so is A∪BA\cup BA∪B.
    • proof. we know A≈2Z,B≈2Z+1A\approx2\mathbb{Z},B\approx2\mathbb{Z}+1A≈2Z,B≈2Z+1. then we naturally have one-to-one function that maps even+odd numbers to integers, then to naturals. □\square□
  2. if there are finite countable sets A1,A2,...A_1,A_2,...A1​,A2​,... that are countable, then so is ⋃i∈NAi\bigcup_{i\in\mathbb{N}}A_i⋃i∈N​Ai​.

corollary. Q\mathbb{Q}Q is countable.
because you can use a pairs of naturals to represent rationals, then union them.

theorem. some further notes about sizes of infinite sets:

  1. every infinite set AAA has a proper subset BBB such that ∣A∣=∣B∣|A|=|B|∣A∣=∣B∣.
  2. for pairs of infinite sets A,BA,BA,B, then ∣A∪B∣=max⁡{∣A∣,∣B∣}|A\cup B|=\max\{|A|,|B|\}∣A∪B∣=max{∣A∣,∣B∣}
  3. for every infinite set AAA and natural number nnn, ∣An∣=∣A∣|A^n|=|A|∣An∣=∣A∣
    1. it is not the case if nnn is infinite, eg ∣NN∣>∣N∣|\mathbb{N}^\mathbb{N}|>|\mathbb{N}|∣NN∣>∣N∣

regular languages
computation devices tasks
DFA given some language and a word,
does this word belong to the language?

defn.

  1. an alphabet Σ\SigmaΣ is any finite set of symbols
  2. for all n∈Nn\in\mathbb{N}n∈N, Σn:=Σ×...×Σ\Sigma^n:=\Sigma\times...\times\SigmaΣn:=Σ×...×Σ (n times) is the set of all sequences a1...ana_1...a_na1​...an​ such that for all i≤ni\leq ni≤n we have ai∈Σa_i\in\Sigmaai​∈Σ
  3. Σ∗:=⋃n∈NΣn\Sigma^*:=\bigcup_{n\in\mathbb{N}}\Sigma^nΣ∗:=⋃n∈N​Σn, ie the set of all finite sequence of members of Σ\SigmaΣ
  4. a language is a subset of Σ∗\Sigma^*Σ∗.

every alphabet Σ\SigmaΣ that we discuss will be finite.

theorem. ∣Σn∣=∣Σ∣n|\Sigma^n|=|\Sigma|^n∣Σn∣=∣Σ∣n.

theorem. Σ∗≈N\Sigma^*\approx\mathbb{N}Σ∗≈N, ie it is countable.

theorem. the set of all languages over Σ∗\Sigma^*Σ∗ is not countable.
proof. P(Σ∗)≈P(N)≈R\mathcal{P}(\Sigma^*)\approx\mathcal{P}(\mathbb{N})\approx\mathbb{R}P(Σ∗)≈P(N)≈R. □\square□

defn. a deterministic automaton (DFA) is a 5-tuple:

  • Σ\SigmaΣ the alphabet of inputs to A
  • QQQ: finite set of states of A
  • q0∈Aq_0\in Aq0​∈A: the initial state
  • δ:Q×Σ→Q\delta:Q\times\Sigma\rightarrow Qδ:Q×Σ→Q: a transition function
  • F⊆QF\subseteq QF⊆Q: accepting states

defn. the language LLL is accepted by AAA, ie w=σ1...σn∈L(A)w=\sigma_1...\sigma_n\in L(A)w=σ1​...σn​∈L(A) iff ∃x1,...,xn∈Q\exists x_1,...,x_n\in Q∃x1​,...,xn​∈Q such that x0=q0x_0=q_0x0​=q0​ and ∀i xi+1=δ(xi,Σi+1)\forall i\, x_{i+1}=\delta(x_i,\Sigma_{i+1})∀ixi+1​=δ(xi​,Σi+1​) and xn∈Fx_n\in Fxn​∈F.

accepting state is q0.

how can we prove that the language is accepted by A? one way of providing such statement is, for every state qi∈Qq_i\in Qqi​∈Q, let L(qi)={w:upon reading w we end in state qi}L(q_i)=\{w:\text{upon reading }w\text{ we end in state }q_i\}L(qi​)={w:upon reading w we end in state qi​}. describe each language L(qi)L(q_i)L(qi​) and prove by induction on the length of www that w∈L(qi)w\in L(q_i)w∈L(qi​) iff it satisfies properties.

theorem. there are languages L⊆Σ∗L\subseteq\Sigma^*L⊆Σ∗ such that no DFA accepts it.
proof. for every nonempty alphabet Σ\SigmaΣ we have Σ∗=∣N∣=ℵ0\Sigma^*=|\mathbb{N}|=\alef_0Σ∗=∣N∣=ℵ0​, then {L:L⊆Σ∗}=∣P(N)∣>ℵ0\{L:L\subseteq\Sigma^*\}=|\mathcal{P}(\mathbb{N})|>\alef_0{L:L⊆Σ∗}=∣P(N)∣>ℵ0​, so the number of languages uncountable. we claim the number of DFAs over a given Σ\SigmaΣ is countable. let Wn={A:A is DFA with at most n states}W_n=\{A:A\text{ is DFA with at most }n\text{ states}\}Wn​={A:A is DFA with at most n states}, then we have at most nn∣Σ∣n^{n|\Sigma|}nn∣Σ∣ possible transition tables. recall that A=(q0,{q0,...,qn−1},δ,F)A=(q_0,\{q_0,...,q_{n-1}\},\delta,F)A=(q0​,{q0​,...,qn−1​},δ,F), the number of possible FFF is 2n2^n2n, so ∣Wn∣≤nnn∣Σ∣2n|W_n|\leq nn^{n|\Sigma|}2^n∣Wn​∣≤nnn∣Σ∣2n is finite. hence the set DFAs is countable, but the number of languages are not. we cannot cover all the languages. □\square□

definition. a regular language is a language that is accepted by a DFA.

corollary. the number of regular languages based on Σ\SigmaΣ is countable.

theorem. (closure properties of the set of regular languages)

  1. closure under complement: if LLL is a regular language then so is L‾={w:w∉L}\overline{L}=\{w:w\notin L\}L={w:w∈/L}

    • proof. flip the accepting states. □\square□

  2. if both L1,L2L_1,L_2L1​,L2​ are regular, then so is L1∪L2L_1\cup L_2L1​∪L2​

    • proof. let A1=(Σ,Q1,δ1,F1,q01),A2=(Σ,Q2,δ2,F2,q01)A_1=(\Sigma,Q_1,\delta_1,F_1,q_0^1),A_2=(\Sigma,Q_2,\delta_2,F_2,q_0^1)A1​=(Σ,Q1​,δ1​,F1​,q01​),A2​=(Σ,Q2​,δ2​,F2​,q01​) be such that L(A1)=L1,L(A2)=L2L(A_1)=L_1,L(A_2)=L_2L(A1​)=L1​,L(A2​)=L2​. let the new DFA be Au=(Σ,Qu,δu,Fu,q0u)A_u=(\Sigma,Q_u,\delta_u,F_u,q_0^u)Au​=(Σ,Qu​,δu​,Fu​,q0u​) where
      • Qu=Q1×Q2Q_u=Q_1\times Q_2Qu​=Q1​×Q2​
      • q0u=(q01,q02)q_0^u=(q_0^1,q_0^2)q0u​=(q01​,q02​)
      • δu((qi,qj),σ)=(δ1(q1,σ),δ2(qj,σ))\delta_u((q_i,q_j),\sigma)=(\delta_1(q_1,\sigma),\delta_2(q_j,\sigma))δu​((qi​,qj​),σ)=(δ1​(q1​,σ),δ2​(qj​,σ))
      • Fu=F1×Q2∪Q1×F2={(qi,qj):either q1∈F1 or q2∈F2}F_u=F_1\times Q_2\cup Q_1\times F_2=\{(q_i,q_j):\text{either }q_1\in F_1\text{ or }q_2\in F_2\}Fu​=F1​×Q2​∪Q1​×F2​={(qi​,qj​):either q1​∈F1​ or q2​∈F2​}.

    use induction to show it satisfies. □\square□

  3. if both L1,L2L_1,L_2L1​,L2​ are regular, then so is L1∩L2L_1\cap L_2L1​∩L2​.

    • pf. same but F∩=F1×F2F^\cap=F_1\times F_2F∩=F1​×F2​. □\square□

Week 3. Jan 17

defn. a non-deterministic automaton (NFA) is a tuple N=(Σ,Q,δ,F,q0)N=(\Sigma,Q,\delta,F,q_0)N=(Σ,Q,δ,F,q0​) where

  1. δ:Q×(Σ∪{ϵ})→P(Q)\delta:Q\times(\Sigma\cup\{\epsilon\})\rightarrow\mathcal{P}(Q)δ:Q×(Σ∪{ϵ})→P(Q)

or informally, NFA is a DFA plus following relaxations:

  1. allowing multiple same-label transition out of state
  2. allowing $\epsilon$-transition (switching between states without reading an input symbol)

defn. the language LLL is accepted by NNN, ie w∈L(N)w\in L(N)w∈L(N) iff ∃w‾\exists\overline{w}∃w obtained from www by inserting the symbol ϵ\epsilonϵ in as many places and ∃x1,...,xm\exists x_1,...,x_m∃x1​,...,xm​ such that x1=q0x_1=q_0x1​=q0​ ∀i xi+1∈δ(xi,yi)\forall i\,x_{i+1}\in\delta(x_i,y_i)∀ixi+1​∈δ(xi​,yi​) where yiy_iyi​ is ith symbol in w‾\overline{w}w and ym∈Fy_m\in Fym​∈F.

eg. given DFA's A1,A2A_1,A_2A1​,A2​ construct A3A_3A3​ accepting L(A1)∪L(A2)L(A_1)\cup L(A_2)L(A1​)∪L(A2​)

eg. let L={w∈{0,1}∗:third-last symbol in w is 1}L=\{w\in\{0,1\}^*:\text{third-last symbol in }w\text{ is }1\}L={w∈{0,1}∗:third-last symbol in w is 1} = {111, 000100, 00101, ...}.

we can choose many paths. if any path leads us to an accepting state then w is accepted.

using DFA, we would remember the last 3 letters and each correspond to a state.

theorem. (closure properties of the set of languages accepted by NFAs)

  1. closure under concatenation: if L1,L2L_1,L_2L1​,L2​ are accepted by N1,N2N_1,N_2N1​,N2​, respectively, then L1∘L2={w1w2:w1∈L1,w2∈L2}L_1\circ L_2=\{w_1w_2:w_1\in L_1,w_2\in L_2\}L1​∘L2​={w1​w2​:w1​∈L1​,w2​∈L2​} is accepted by an NFA.
    • proof. we chain N1N_1N1​ and N2N_2N2​: let the accepting states of N1N_1N1​ transit to the starting state of N2N_2N2​ using ϵ\epsilonϵ, and let the accepting states of N1N_1N1​ be no longer accepted. □\square□
  2. closure under * operation: given language LLL accepted by NNN, let L0=∅,L1=L,Ln+1=LnLL_0=\varnothing,L_1=L,L_{n+1}=L_nLL0​=∅,L1​=L,Ln+1​=Ln​L, then L∗=⋃n∈NLn={w1...wn:wi∈Σ,n∈N}L^*=\bigcup_{n\in\mathbb{N}}L_n=\{w_1...w_n:w_i\in\Sigma,n\in\mathbb{N}\}L∗=⋃n∈N​Ln​={w1​...wn​:wi​∈Σ,n∈N} is accepted by an NFA.
    • proof. construct N∗N^*N∗ with a new starting state q∗q_*q∗​ which is also accepted, and transits to starting state of NNN, q0q_0q0​, using ϵ\epsilonϵ. let all the accepting states of NNN transit to q0q_0q0​ via ϵ\epsilonϵ. □\square□

remark. if we do not add this new q∗q_*q∗​ but reuse q0q_0q0​ we would have error: a word finishes scanning and land on non-accepting state which can transit to q0q_0q0​, then this word is suddenly accepted.

theorem. a language LLL is accepted by an DFA iff is accepted by a NFA.
proof.

  • (forward) every DFA is also an NFA.
  • (backward) given some NFA N=(Q,q0,δ,Σ,F)N=(Q,q_0,\delta,\Sigma,F)N=(Q,q0​,δ,Σ,F), construct A=(Q′,q0′,δ′,Σ,F′)A=(Q',q_0',\delta',\Sigma,F')A=(Q′,q0′​,δ′,Σ,F′) where
    • Q′=P(Q)Q'=\mathcal{P}(Q)Q′=P(Q)
    • q′={q0}q'=\{q_0\}q′={q0​}
    • δ′(R,a)=⋃q∈Rδ(E(q),a)\delta'(R,a)=\bigcup_{q\in R}\delta(E(q),a)δ′(R,a)=⋃q∈R​δ(E(q),a) where E(q)E(q)E(q) is the set of states reachable from qqq via ϵ-transitions only
    • F′={w⊆Q:w∩F≠∅}F'=\{w\subseteq Q:w\cap F\neq\varnothing\}F′={w⊆Q:w∩F=∅} □\square□

corollary. a language is regular is regular iff it is accepted by an NFA.

corollary. the set of all regular languages is closed by union, intersection, concatenation and star.

theorem. every finite language is regular.
proof. let L={w1,...,wn}L=\{w_1,...,w_n\}L={w1​,...,wn​}. we know for every word wi=ai1...aikiw_i=a_{i1}...a_{ik_i}wi​=ai1​...aiki​​, the individual letters {ai1},...{aiki}\{a_{i1}\},...\{a_{ik_i}\}{ai1​},...{aiki​​} are regular, by closure of concatenation, we know for every word wiw_iwi​, Lwi={wi}={ai1...aiki}L_{w_i}=\{w_i\}=\{a_{i1}...a_{ik_i}\}Lwi​​={wi​}={ai1​...aiki​​} is regular. by closure of union we know L=Lw1∪...∪LwnL=L_{w_1}\cup...\cup L_{w_n}L=Lw1​​∪...∪Lwn​​ is regular. □\square□

theorem. every regular language can be derived from these basic languages by a finite sequence of closure operations.

inductive definition of regular languages

we can define sets in 3 ways:

  • listing all elements
  • describing common properties
  • inductive definition: define domain (universe) XXX, core set AAA, and operations OOO, then I(X,A,O)I(X,A,O)I(X,A,O) is minimal set WWW containing AAA and is closed under operations in OOO.
    1. we will require both XXX and AAA are defined and
    2. A⊆XA\subseteq XA⊆X
    3. O is a set of functions from XnX^nXn to XXX

eg. X = all human beings, A = {me}, O = {parent of, child of, spouse of}. my blood relatives are I(X,A,O).

theorem. if W1,W2W_1,W_2W1​,W2​ are two sets that contain AAA and is closed under OOO, then W1∩W2W_1\cap W_2W1​∩W2​ also contains AAA and is closed under OOO.

theorem. (minimality) define W=⋂iWiW=\bigcap_iW_iW=⋂i​Wi​ where WiW_iWi​'s are all sets that contain AAA and is closed under OOO, then not only WWW contain AAA and is closed under OOO, but also is minimal in this respect.
proof. because if any set W‾\overline{W}W satisfies the properties, then it is among the sets intersected in the definition of WWW, so W⊆W‾W\subseteq\overline{W}W⊆W. □\square□

theorem. such W=⋂iWiW=\bigcap_i W_iW=⋂i​Wi​ is unique.

eg. assume we know real numbers, define natural numbers: I(R,{0},{x↦x+1})=NI(\mathbb{R},\{0\},\{x\mapsto x+1\})=\mathbb{N}I(R,{0},{x↦x+1})=N.

eg. define set of all polynomials with integer coefficients.

eg. set of all propositional formulas.

inductive sets have the ability to prove properties by structural induction.

  • formally: let R⊆XR\subseteq XR⊆X be some property, if A⊆RA\subseteq RA⊆R and whenever [x1,...,xn]∈Rn[x_1,...,x_n]\in R^n[x1​,...,xn​]∈Rn so is f(x1,...,xn)f(x_1,...,x_n)f(x1​,...,xn​) for every f∈Of\in Of∈O, then I(X,A,O)⊆RI(X,A,O)\subseteq RI(X,A,O)⊆R.

eg. have 3 cups initially positioned as ∪∩∪, one can flip two cups each time. can i finally flip all of them upright?

  • base set: {∪∩∪}
  • operations: {flip left two, flip right two, flip two ends}
  • property: number of upright cups is even.
    1. for base set: we know ∪∩∪ satisfies property.
    2. if we have a configuration ccc satisfying this property, if we flip two, then either i flipped two in same position => number changed by 2 => no effect on oddity; or i flipped one up and one down => number does not change. so we still have even number.
    3. we can never have all cups upright (∪∪∪ is outside R). □\square□

we can use inductive sets to revisit regular expressions.

defn. set of regular expressions is I=(alphabet∗,A,O)I=(\text{alphabet}^*,A,O)I=(alphabet∗,A,O) where:

  1. alphabet: Σ∪{ϵ,∅,(,),∘,∗,∪}\Sigma\cup\{\epsilon,\varnothing,(,),\circ,*,\cup\}Σ∪{ϵ,∅,(,),∘,∗,∪}
  2. core: A=Σ∪{ϵ,∅}A=\Sigma\cup\{\epsilon,\varnothing\}A=Σ∪{ϵ,∅}
  3. operations: O={R1,R2R1∪R2,R1,R2R1∘R2,R1R1∗}O=\{\frac{R_1,R_2}{R_1\cup R_2},\frac{R_1,R_2}{R_1\circ R_2},\frac{R_1}{R_1^*}\}O={R1​∪R2​R1​,R2​​,R1​∘R2​R1​,R2​​,R1∗​R1​​}

we can generate ϵ,a,b,a∘b,a∗,(a∪b)∗\epsilon,a,b,a\circ b,a^*,(a\cup b)^*ϵ,a,b,a∘b,a∗,(a∪b)∗, etc.

for simplicity we omit "∘\circ∘", and delete brackets according to priorities: ∗>∘>∪* >\circ>\cup∗>∘>∪. it is also common to use +++ instead of ∪\cup∪.

theorem. for alphabet Σ\SigmaΣ, we define a function LLL that maps regular expressions to languages for every regular expression rrr such that L(r)L(r)L(r) is subset of Σ∗\Sigma^*Σ∗

  1. L(∅)=∅L(\varnothing)=\varnothingL(∅)=∅ (empty expression -> empty language)
  2. L(ϵ)={ϵ}L(\epsilon)=\{\epsilon\}L(ϵ)={ϵ}
  3. L(a)={a}L(a)=\{a\}L(a)={a} for every a∈Σa\in\Sigmaa∈Σ
  4. L(R1∪R2)=L(R1)∪L(R2)L(R_1\cup R_2)=L(R_1)\cup L(R_2)L(R1​∪R2​)=L(R1​)∪L(R2​)
  5. L(R1R2)=L(R1)L(R2)L(R_1R_2)=L(R_1)L(R_2)L(R1​R2​)=L(R1​)L(R2​)
  6. L(R∗)=(L(R))∗L(R^*)=(L(R))^*L(R∗)=(L(R))∗

such LLL is well-defined.
idea. this is well defined whenever I(X,A,O) has a unique readability property, ie for every r∈I(X,A,O)r\in I(X,A,O)r∈I(X,A,O), either r∈Ar\in Ar∈A or there are uniquely defined f∈Of\in Of∈O and r1,r2∈I(X,A,O)r_1,r_2\in I(X,A,O)r1​,r2​∈I(X,A,O) such that f(r1,r2)=rf(r_1,r_2)=rf(r1​,r2​)=r.

remark. why do we need ∅\varnothing∅ in definition of regular languages? because there are languages that do not accept anything, and we need a mapping from regular languages to it.

eg. assume Σ={a,b}\Sigma=\{a,b\}Σ={a,b}, let L1=L_1=L1​= all strings containing aaa, r=(a∪b)∗a(a∪b)∗r=(a\cup b)^*a(a\cup b)^*r=(a∪b)∗a(a∪b)∗, then L(r)=L1L(r)=L_1L(r)=L1​.

eg. let r=(a+b)∅r=(a+b)\varnothingr=(a+b)∅, what is L(r)L(r)L(r)? it is ∅\varnothing∅ because it is followed by empty set => cannot generate.

eg. find rrr such that L(r)=L(r)=L(r)= all strings where every aaa is immediately followed by a bbb. r=((ϵ∪a)b)∗r=((\epsilon\cup a)b)^*r=((ϵ∪a)b)∗.

defn. a generalized non deterministic automaton (GNFA) is a tuple (Σ,Q,q0,qF,δ)(\Sigma,Q,q_0,q_F,\delta)(Σ,Q,q0​,qF​,δ)

  1. Σ\SigmaΣ: finite alphabet
  2. QQQ: finite states
  3. starting state: q0q_0q0​
  4. accepting states: qFq_FqF​
  5. transitions δ:(Q−{q0})×(Q−{qF})→(Q−{q0})\delta:(Q-\{q_0\})\times(Q-\{q_F\})\rightarrow (Q-\{q_0\})δ:(Q−{q0​})×(Q−{qF​})→(Q−{q0​}): δ\deltaδ defines the labeling of edges in the GNFA, where edges are regular expressions

or informally an NFA where,

  1. there is a unique start state q0q_0q0​ and no arrows go into it
  2. there is a unique end state qFq_FqF​ and no arrows go out of it
  3. every arrow is labeled by a regular expression

defn. a string www is accepted by GNFA DDD, ie w∈L(D)w\in L(D)w∈L(D), iff there exists a path q0...qkqFq_0...q_kq_Fq0​...qk​qF​ such that w=w0w1...wkw=w_0w_1...w_kw=w0​w1​...wk​ and for every i≤ki\leq ki≤k we have wi∈L(δ(qi,qi+1))w_i\in L(\delta(q_i,q_{i+1}))wi​∈L(δ(qi​,qi+1​)) and wk∈L(δ(qk,qF))w_k\in L(\delta(q_k,q_F))wk​∈L(δ(qk​,qF​)). ie we are matching the input word by regexes part by part.

      a*        b*
q0 ------> q1 ------> qF

theorem. for every DFA DDD, there exists a NGFA GGG accepting same language, ie L(D)=L(G)L(D)=L(G)L(D)=L(G).
proof. we need to remove labels entering q0q_0q0​: add a new nonaccepting starting state q‾0\overline{q}_0q​0​ that goes to the original q0q_0q0​ by ϵ. then need to remove labels leaving accepting states: add a new accepting state q‾F\overline{q}_Fq​F​ and any previous accepting states go to it by ϵ. make the previous accepting states non-accepting.

if we have self-loops q1→q2q_1\rightarrow q_2q1​→q2​ by aaa, we can star it: a∗a^*a∗.

then we relabel using regexes and eliminate useless states. given any GNFA G=(Σ,Q,q0,qF,δ),Q={q0,...,qk,qF}G=(\Sigma,Q,q_0,q_F,\delta),Q=\{q_0,...,q_k,q_F\}G=(Σ,Q,q0​,qF​,δ),Q={q0​,...,qk​,qF​}, we will construct GNFA's G1,...,GkG_1,...,G_kG1​,...,Gk​ such that Q(Gi+1)=Q(Gi)−{qi}Q(G_{i+1})=Q(G_i)-\{q_i\}Q(Gi+1​)=Q(Gi​)−{qi​} and L(Gi+1)=L(Gi)L(G_{i+1})=L(G_i)L(Gi+1​)=L(Gi​), Q(Gk)={q0,qF}Q(G_k)=\{q_0,q_F\}Q(Gk​)={q0​,qF​} (?). connect any qqq with an edge leading into qiq_iqi​ to any node with an arrow from qiq_iqi​ to that state

(if state q1q_1q1​ goes to q2q_2q2​ by two arrows r1,r2r_1,r_2r1​,r2​, then replace two arrows by a single one r1+r2r_1+r_2r1​+r2​)

we shrink edges until we only have two states from q0q_0q0​ to qFq_FqF​. □\square□

we now have the third type of automaton aside from DFA and NFA, we we can show the following theorem.

theorem. for every Σ\SigmaΣ, {L(r):r is regular expression over Σ}={L(A):A is a DFA over Σ}=\{L(r):r\text{ is regular expression over }\Sigma\}=\{L(A):A\text{ is a DFA over }\Sigma\}={L(r):r is regular expression over Σ}={L(A):A is a DFA over Σ}= all regular languages over Σ∗\Sigma^*Σ∗.
proof. we want to show for a regular expression rrr, there exists some DFA ArA_rAr​ such that L(Ar)=L(r)L(A_r)=L(r)L(Ar​)=L(r). we know regular expressions = I(X=strings, A={∅,ϵ}∪Σ, O={...}), we want to show it has equivalent automaton. by induction, base: we just show each member AAA has a DFA:

  • ∅ (rejects everything): just a single starting state q0q_0q0​ non-accepting, and transits everything to itself
  • ϵ (accepts only empty string): one starting state q0q_0q0​ accepting, and it transits to q1q_1q1​ via ϵ non-accepting. q1q_1q1​ transits to itself via ϵ.
  • Σ: one starting state q0q_0q0​ non accepting, transits to an accepting state by letters in Σ

induction: let r1,r2r_1,r_2r1​,r2​ be regular expressions, assume there are DFAs D1,D2D_1,D_2D1​,D2​ s.t. L(D1)=L(r1),L(D2)=L(r2)L(D_1)=L(r_1),L(D_2)=L(r_2)L(D1​)=L(r1​),L(D2​)=L(r2​) (IH), we want to show after operations IH still holds:

  • show there exists D3D_3D3​ s.t. L(D3)=L(r1∪r2)=L(r1)∪L(r2)L(D_3)=L(r_1\cup r_2)=L(r_1)\cup L(r_2)L(D3​)=L(r1​∪r2​)=L(r1​)∪L(r2​): recall the family of regular languages is closed under union and result is still regex, by IH it has an D3D_3D3​.
  • show there exists D3D_3D3​ s.t. L(D3)=L(r1r2)=L(r1)L(r2)L(D_3)=L(r_1r_2)=L(r_1)L(r_2)L(D3​)=L(r1​r2​)=L(r1​)L(r2​): recall the family of regular languages is closed under union...
  • show there exists D3D_3D3​ s.t. L(D3)=L(r∗)=L(r)∗L(D_3)=L(r^*)=L(r)^*L(D3​)=L(r∗)=L(r)∗: recall the closure of regular languages under *...

so for every regular expression rrr there exists some DFA DDD s.t. L(D)=L(r)L(D)=L(r)L(D)=L(r), and left ⊆ right.

the remaining direction is for every DFA, there is a same regular language. we just convert it into a GNFA with only two states. the regex on the edge is the regular expression we want. □\square□

the pumping lemma

corollary. for every Σ\SigmaΣ there exists L⊆Σ∗L\subseteq\Sigma^*L⊆Σ∗ that is not regular.
proof. we know the set of languages is uncountable and set of DFAs over Σ∗\Sigma^*Σ∗ is countable (so set of regular expressions over Σ∗\Sigma^*Σ∗ is countable). □\square□

can we point to a non-regular language?

theorem. (the pumping lemma) for every regular language LLL there exist some number nLn_LnL​ such that for every w∈Lw\in Lw∈L such that ∣w∣>nL|w|>n_L∣w∣>nL​ there is a partition of www into sections w=xyzw=xyzw=xyz satisfying:

  1. ∣xy∣≤nL|xy|\leq n_L∣xy∣≤nL​,
  2. y≠ϵy\neq\epsilony=ϵ,
  3. ∀i∈N∈xyiz∈L\forall i\in\N\in xy^iz\in L∀i∈N∈xyiz∈L.

proof. let AAA be a DFA accepting LLL and let nLn_LnL​ denote number of states in AAA. let w∈Lw\in Lw∈L with ∣w∣>nL|w|>n_L∣w∣>nL​, consider the sequence of states q0,δ(q0σ1),,δ(q0σ1σ2),...,δ(q0σ1...σm)q_0,\delta(q_0\sigma_1),,\delta(q_0\sigma_1\sigma_2),...,\delta(q_0\sigma_1...\sigma_m)q0​,δ(q0​σ1​),,δ(q0​σ1​σ2​),...,δ(q0​σ1​...σm​) where w=σ1...σmw=\sigma_1...\sigma_mw=σ1​...σm​, then there exists σr,σs\sigma_r,\sigma_sσr​,σs​ such that δ(q0σ1...σn)=δ(q0σ1...σnσr...σs)\delta(q_0\sigma_1...\sigma_n)=\delta(q_0\sigma_1...\sigma_n\sigma_r...\sigma_s)δ(q0​σ1​...σn​)=δ(q0​σ1​...σn​σr​...σs​) (we are repeating some states).

now define x=σ1...σn,y=σr+1...σs,z=σ=δs+1...σmx=\sigma_1...\sigma_n,y=\sigma_{r+1}...\sigma_s,z=\sigma=\delta_{s+1}...\sigma_mx=σ1​...σn​,y=σr+1​...σs​,z=σ=δs+1​...σm​ by picking rrr such that δ(q0σ1...σr)\delta(q_0\sigma_1...\sigma_r)δ(q0​σ1​...σr​) is different than any δ(q0...qi)\delta(q_0...q_i)δ(q0​...qi​) for any i<ni<ni<n and that δ(q0σ1...σr+1),σ(q0σ1...σr+2),...,δ(q0σ1...σs)\delta(q_0\sigma_1...\sigma_{r+1}),\sigma(q_0\sigma_1...\sigma_{r+2}),...,\delta(q_0\sigma_1...\sigma_s)δ(q0​σ1​...σr+1​),σ(q0​σ1​...σr+2​),...,δ(q0​σ1​...σs​) are all different, we are guaranteed that ∣xy∣≤nL|xy|\leq n_L∣xy∣≤nL​. then δ(q0σ1...σr(σr+1...σs)iσs+1...σm)=δ(q0σ1...σr(σr+1...σs)jσs+1...σm)\delta(q_0\sigma_1...\sigma_r(\sigma_{r+1}...\sigma_s)^i\sigma_{s+1}...\sigma_m)=\delta(q_0\sigma_1...\sigma_r(\sigma_{r+1}...\sigma_s)^j\sigma_{s+1}...\sigma_m)δ(q0​σ1​...σr​(σr+1​...σs​)iσs+1​...σm​)=δ(q0​σ1​...σr​(σr+1​...σs​)jσs+1​...σm​) for all i,j∈Ni,j\in\Ni,j∈N. □\square□

  • converse is not true

eg. given L={anbn:n∈N}L=\{a^nb^n:n\in\N\}L={anbn:n∈N}, show it is not regular.
pick any nLn_LnL​, given a word w=anL+1bnL+1∈Lw=a^{n_L+1}b^{n_L+1}\in Lw=anL​+1bnL​+1∈L, since we want to have ∣xy∣≤nL|xy|\leq n_L∣xy∣≤nL​ we pick partition xyxyxy to be a sequence of aaa's. then xy2zxy^2zxy2z will have nL+1+∣y∣n_L+1+|y|nL​+1+∣y∣ aaa's and nL+1n_L+1nL​+1 bbb's, which is not in LLL, failing the pumping lemma (3). □\square□

eg. show palindromes L={wwR:w∈{a,b}∗}L=\{ww^R:w\in\{a,b\}^*\}L={wwR:w∈{a,b}∗} is not regular.
consider w=anL+1bbanL+1w=a^{n_L+1}bba^{n_L+1}w=anL​+1bbanL​+1.

eg. (languages over an alphabet with just one symbol) let L⊆{a}∗,Ln={w∈L:∣w∣=n}L\subseteq\{a\}^*,L_n=\{w\in L:|w|=n\}L⊆{a}∗,Ln​={w∈L:∣w∣=n}, show every infinite language KKK where for arbitrarily large numbers kkk there exists nkn_knk​ such that for all nk≤i≤nk+kn_k\leq i\leq n_k+knk​≤i≤nk​+k such that Li=∅L_i=\varnothingLi​=∅ is not regular.

given any number there is a hole of that length
a aa ... a^5 a^6 a^7 ... a^15 a^16

pick any nLn_LnL​, and pick any k>nLk>n_Lk>nL​ such that w:=ak∈Kw:=a^k\in Kw:=ak∈K and for all i≤nL+1i\leq n_L+1i≤nL​+1 we have ak+i∉Ka^{k+i}\notin Kak+i∈/K. then let xyzxyzxyz be any partition of this word such that ∣xy∣≤nL|xy|\leq n_L∣xy∣≤nL​, then ∣xy2z∣=∣w∣+∣y∣≤k+nL<k+nL+1|xy^2z|=|w|+|y|\leq k+n_L<k+n_L+1∣xy2z∣=∣w∣+∣y∣≤k+nL​<k+nL​+1 and it is not in KKK. □\square□

the machine will lose track of states and 'sleep' after rejecting too many.

eg. {an2:n∈N}\{a^{n^2}:n\in\N\}{an2:n∈N} is not regular.
because the gap between n2n^2n2 and (n+1)2(n+1)^2(n+1)2 can be arbitrarily large.

eg. {ap:p is prime}\{a^p:p\text{ is prime}\}{ap:p is prime} is not regular.
it is an infinite language but for every kkk there exists a prime number ppp such that p+1,...,p+kp+1,...,p+kp+1,...,p+k is not in the language.

eg. show L={w∈{a,b}∗:#a(w)≠#b(w)}L=\{w\in\{a,b\}^*:\#_a(w)\neq\#_b(w)\}L={w∈{a,b}∗:#a​(w)=#b​(w)} is not regular.
use closure property. consider {ab}∗−L=anbn\{ab\}^*-L=a^nb^n{ab}∗−L=anbn, we know it not is regular either by last example, but it should if LLL were regular. □\square□

combinatorial definition of regular languages

the pumping lemma is not a characteristic of regular languages, but MN theorem is.

defn. given a language L⊆Σ∗L\subseteq\Sigma^*L⊆Σ∗, we say w,w′∈Σ∗w,w'\in\Sigma^*w,w′∈Σ∗ are distinguishable with respect to LLL if there exists some z∈Σ∗z\in\Sigma^*z∈Σ∗ such that one of wz,w′zwz,w'zwz,w′z is in LLL and the other is not.

claim. given LLL we define an equivalence relation over Σ∗\Sigma^*Σ∗ by w≡Lw′w\equiv_Lw'w≡L​w′ if w,w′w,w'w,w′ are not distinguishable via LLL.
proof.

  • reflexivity: clear
  • transitivity: let w1≡Lw2,w2≡Lw3w_1\equiv_L w_2,w_2\equiv_L w_3w1​≡L​w2​,w2​≡L​w3​, then for all zzz, w1z∈L  ⟺  w2z∈L  ⟺  w3z∈Lw_1z\in L\iff w_2z\in L\iff w_3z\in Lw1​z∈L⟺w2​z∈L⟺w3​z∈L so w1≡Lw3w_1\equiv_L w_3w1​≡L​w3​.
  • commutativity: clear □\square□

using this relation we can partition Σ∗\Sigma^*Σ∗ into equivalence classes.

eg. let Le={w:∣w∣∈2N}L_e=\{w:|w|\in2\N\}Le​={w:∣w∣∈2N}. then ababab and abbabbabb are distinguishable (a simplest empty string as zzz will work). we can also partition Σ∗\Sigma^*Σ∗ into two equivalence classes (even length and odd).

eg. let L={anbk:n,k∈N}L=\{a^nb^k:n,k\in\N\}L={anbk:n,k∈N}. then there are infinitely many equivalent classes {w:#a(w)−#b(w)=i}\{w:\#_a(w)-\#_b(w)=i\}{w:#a​(w)−#b​(w)=i} for all iii...

eg. let Lk={w∈Σ∗:#a(w)≤k}L_k=\{w\in\Sigma^*:\#_a(w)\leq k\}Lk​={w∈Σ∗:#a​(w)≤k}. depending on how many aaa's there are k+2k+2k+2 equivalent classes.

  • Wi={w:#a(w)=i}W_{i}=\{w:\#_a(w)= i\}Wi​={w:#a​(w)=i} for 0≤i≤k0\leq i\leq k0≤i≤k
  • W>k={w:#a(w)>k}W_{>k}=\{w:\#_a(w)> k\}W>k​={w:#a​(w)>k}

theorem. (Myhill Nerode) a language LLL is regular iff the number of equivalence classes of ≡L\equiv_L≡L​ is finite. furthermore, the number of equivalence classes is the number the minimal number of states in any DFA for LLL.

  • equivalently: L is regular iff number of subsets W⊆Σ∗W\subseteq\Sigma^*W⊆Σ∗ such that every two of its elements are distinguishable by LLL, is finite.

proof.

  • assume LLL is regular. then there are a DFA D=(Σ,Q,q0,δ,F)D=(\Sigma,Q,q_0,\delta,F)D=(Σ,Q,q0​,δ,F) that accepts LLL. note for every q∈Qq\in Qq∈Q, {w∈Σ∗:δ(q0,w)=q}\{w\in\Sigma^*:\delta(q_0,w)=q\}{w∈Σ∗:δ(q0​,w)=q} (final state) is an ≡L\equiv_L≡L​ equivalence class, by that for every z∈Σ∗z\in\Sigma^*z∈Σ∗, any words concatenated with zzz, w,w′w,w'w,w′ will re-start at the same previous final state (q), so wz,w′zwz,w'zwz,w′z must be (un)distinguishable at the same time.
    • corollary. the number of ≡L\equiv_L≡L​ equivalence classes is less than ∣Q∣|Q|∣Q∣ and therefore finite.
  • assume the number of ≡L\equiv_L≡L​ equivalence classes is finite. for a word www, let [w]L[w]_L[w]L​ denote its belonging ≡L\equiv_L≡L​ class. construct a DFA D=(Σ,Q,q0,δ,F)D=(\Sigma,Q,q_0,\delta,F)D=(Σ,Q,q0​,δ,F) by letting
    • Q={w⊆Σ∗:W is equivalence class to ≡L}Q=\{w\subseteq\Sigma^*:W\text{ is equivalence class to }\equiv_L\}Q={w⊆Σ∗:W is equivalence class to ≡L​}
    • q0=[ϵ]Lq_0=[\epsilon]_Lq0​=[ϵ]L​
    • δ([w]L,σ)=[wσ]L\delta([w]_L,\sigma)=[w\sigma]_Lδ([w]L​,σ)=[wσ]L​
    • F={[w]L:w∈L}F=\{[w]_L:w\in L\}F={[w]L​:w∈L}.
    • for all w∈Σ∗w\in\Sigma^*w∈Σ∗, we have δ(q0,w)=[w]L\delta(q_0,w)=[w]_Lδ(q0​,w)=[w]L​, so L(D)={w∈Σ∗:δ(q0,w)∈F}={w∈Σ∗:[w]L∈F}={w∈Σ∗:w∈L}L(D)=\{w\in\Sigma^*:\delta(q_0,w)\in F\}=\{w\in\Sigma^*:[w]_L\in F\}=\{w\in\Sigma^*:w\in L\}L(D)={w∈Σ∗:δ(q0​,w)∈F}={w∈Σ∗:[w]L​∈F}={w∈Σ∗:w∈L}.
  • we have ∣Q∣≤|Q|\leq∣Q∣≤ number of equivalence classes. the equivalence classes of ≡L\equiv_L≡L​ are merges of the difference kinds of inputs so number of equivalence classes ≤∣Q∣\leq|Q|≤∣Q∣. □\square□

eg. show L={w=w1...wn∈{a,b}∗:n≥k,wn−k+1=a}L=\{w=w_1...w_n\in\{a,b\}^*:n\geq k,w_{n-k+1}=a\}L={w=w1​...wn​∈{a,b}∗:n≥k,wn−k+1​=a} is regular.
we see w≡Lw′w\equiv_L w'w≡L​w′ iff the last k-long substring in www is the same as the last k-long substring in w′w'w′. so we have 2k2^k2k equivalence classes depending on the available combinations. □\square□

claim. any nonmempty language LLL accepted by a DFA with kkk states must accept some word of length less than or equal to kkk.

context-free languages

every CFL is defined by a context-free grammar. while regular languages are defined by either a DFA/NFA or a regular expression (description), CFL are defined by a method generating the language.

defn. a context-free grammar (CFG) is a tuple G=(Σ,V,S,R)G=(\Sigma,V,S,R)G=(Σ,V,S,R) where

  • Σ\SigmaΣ is the alphabet
  • VVV is a finite set of symbols representing variables, and we require Σ∩V=∅\Sigma\cap V=\varnothingΣ∩V=∅
  • S∈VS\in VS∈V
  • RRR is a finite set of generation rules of the form A→wA\rightarrow wA→w for some A∈V,w∈(V∪Σ)∗A\in V,w\in(V\cup\Sigma)^*A∈V,w∈(V∪Σ)∗

defn. a context-free language for GGG is L=I((Σ∪V)∗,C,O)∩Σ∗L=I((\Sigma\cup V)^*,C,O)\cap\Sigma^*L=I((Σ∪V)∗,C,O)∩Σ∗, where C=SC=SC=S, OOO is a collection of operations w↦w′w\mapsto w'w↦w′ where w=uAv,w′=uw‾vw=uAv,w'=u\overline{w}vw=uAv,w′=uwv and A→w‾∈RA\rightarrow\overline{w}\in RA→w∈R.

eg. show the language for the following grammar is L={0n1n:n∈N}L=\{0^n1^n:n\in\N\}L={0n1n:n∈N}.

Σ: {0,1}
V: {s}
S: s
R: s -> 0s1, s -> ϵ

words before intersection: 0s1, 00ss1, ..., 0000s1111, 00001111, ...
  • language for this CFG = U=I({0,1},{s},O)U=I(\{0,1\}, \{s\}, O)U=I({0,1},{s},O)
  • show U⊆LU\subseteq LU⊆L by structural induction of UUU:
    • showing UUU has the form 0ns1n0^ns1^n0ns1n or 0n1n0^n1^n0n1n
    • base: there is only one element in the core set: sss, and it is in LLL.
    • inductive: assume w=0ns1nw=0^ns1^nw=0ns1n has this form, then using the first rule we have result 0n+1s1n+10^{n+1}s1^{n+1}0n+1s1n+1, using the second rule we have result 0n1n0^n1^n0n1n.
    • this suffices since applying rule 2 removes sss to become 0n1n0^n1^n0n1n
  • show L⊆UL\subseteq UL⊆U by usual induction on nnn:
    • let w=0ns1nw=0^ns1^nw=0ns1n and show it is in UUU
    • base: n=0n=0n=0, then word is sss
    • inductive: assume 0ns1n∈U0^ns1^n\in U0ns1n∈U, then we use rule 1 to get 0n+1s1n+1∈U0^{n+1}s1^{n+1}\in U0n+1s1n+1∈U
    • this suffices because finally applying rule 2 removes sss □\square□

eg. find a CFG to generate L={anbk:n≤k}L=\{a^nb^k:n\leq k\}L={anbk:n≤k}.

Σ: {a,b}
V: {S,T}
S: S
R: S -> aSbT | ϵ
   T -> bT | ϵ

eg. find a CFG to generate L={w∈{a,b}∗:#a(w)=#b(w)}L=\{w\in\{a,b\}^*:\#_a(w)=\#_b(w)\}L={w∈{a,b}∗:#a​(w)=#b​(w)}.

Σ: {a,b}
V: {S}
S: S
R: S -> aSbS | bSaS | ϵ

showing LLL includes this is easy. proving this includes LLL: use induction on ∣w∣|w|∣w∣, assume every 'balanced' w=w1...wnw=w_1...w_nw=w1​...wn​ of length nnn can be generated by the grammar. let mmm be minimum index from which w1...wmw_1...w_mw1​...wm​ is balanced, then we claim w1≠wnw_1\neq w_nw1​=wn​. so w2...wm−1w_2...w_{m-1}w2​...wm−1​ is balanced, so my grammar will generate based on this portion. □\square□

theorem. every regular language is a context-free language.
proof. use induction on all regular languages: I(P(Σ∗),{∅,ϵ}∪Σ,{∪,∘,∗})I(\mathcal{P}(\Sigma^*),\{\varnothing,\epsilon\}\cup\Sigma,\{\cup,\circ,*\})I(P(Σ∗),{∅,ϵ}∪Σ,{∪,∘,∗})

  • base: for empty language ∅\varnothing∅, just use one rule S -> S; for ϵ\epsilonϵ, use rule S -> ϵ; for each a in Σ\SigmaΣ, use rule S -> a to generate the language
  • inductive: assume we have CFG L(G1)=L1,L(G2)=L2L(G_1)=L_1,L(G_2)=L_2L(G1​)=L1​,L(G2​)=L2​
    • L(G1)∪L(G2)L(G_1)\cup L(G_2)L(G1​)∪L(G2​): A -> w, A -> v to A -> w|v
    • L(G1)L(G2)L(G_1)L(G_2)L(G1​)L(G2​): wrap G1G_1G1​'s starting rule S -> w with extra D' -> S and; wrap G2G_2G2​'s T -> v with extra T' -> T. then use new starting symbol C with rule C -> ST
    • L(G1)∗L(G_1)^*L(G1​)∗: wrap starting rule S -> w by S' -> S and use new starting symbol C with rule C -> S'|CC|ϵ □\square□

parse tree: internal nodes are in VVV. leaves are in Σ∗\Sigma^*Σ∗. it describes the generating sequence too.

a parse tree for a given w∈L(G)w\in L(G)w∈L(G) is not necessarily unique.

eg. set of well formed propositional logic expressions

Σ: {(,),∧,∨,¬,→,p1,...,pn}
V = {S}
R = S -> p1 | ... | pn
      | ¬S
      | (S ∧ S)
      | (S ∨ S)
      | (S → S)
      | ϵ

the brackets are necessary to avoid ambiguity (multiple possible pares trees for same expression).

the pumping lemma

the set of context-free languages over an alphabet is countable because derivation rules are finite objects.

defn. the degree of a tree is the max number of down-going edges from any vertex; the height of a tree is the length of the longest branch of the tree.

lemma. for any tree TTT, the number of leaves of T≤dhT\leq d^hT≤dh where d=deg(T),h=height(T)d=\text{deg}(T),h=\text{height}(T)d=deg(T),h=height(T).

note that if T is a derivation tree for a word www in some LLL, then # leaves≥∣w∣\text{\# leaves}\geq|w|# leaves≥∣w∣, and d(T)≤max⁡∣w∣{A→w∈R}d(T)\leq\max_{|w|}\{A\rightarrow w\in R\}d(T)≤max∣w∣​{A→w∈R} (longest word produced by one rule), so h≥log⁡d∣w∣h\geq\log_{d}|w|h≥logd​∣w∣.

theorem. (the CFL pumping lemma) for every CFL LLL, there is some number p∈Np\in Np∈N such that for every w∈Lw\in Lw∈L if ∣w∣>p|w|>p∣w∣>p then there is a partition of www into 5 parts w=xyzuvw=xyzuvw=xyzuv and

  1. ∣yzu∣≤p|yzu|\leq p∣yzu∣≤p,
  2. ∣yu∣≥1|yu|\geq1∣yu∣≥1,
  3. xyizuiv∈Lxy^izu^iv\in Lxyizuiv∈L for all i∈Ni\in\Ni∈N.

proof. let GGG be the grammar and let p=d∣V∣+1p=d^{|V|+1}p=d∣V∣+1 where ddd is the degree of any derivation tree and ∣V∣|V|∣V∣ be number of variables. let w∈L(G)w\in L(G)w∈L(G) be a word longer than ppp. pick a derivation tree for www with minimal possible number of vertices so we have the 'height' of derivation steps h≥∣V∣+1h\geq|V|+1h≥∣V∣+1, which means we must have repeated some variables. consider the two lowest occurrences of such variables, call these nodes A,BA,BA,B and AAA is on the left of BBB. as the leaves of the tree are the word itself, we pick

  1. the leftmost subtree of AAA as xxx,
  2. to the leftmost subtree of BBB as yyy,
  3. to the rightmost subtree of BBB as zzz,
  4. to the rightmost subtree of AAA as uuu,
  5. the rightmost subtree of AAA as vvv.

we can generate powers of yyy and uuu because we can mimic the reuse of variable seen in AAA and BBB in the leaf level. □\square□

eg. let L={anbncn∈{a,b,c}∗:n∈N}L=\{a^nb^nc^n\in\{a,b,c\}^*:n\in\N\}L={anbncn∈{a,b,c}∗:n∈N}, show it is not context-free.
given any p∈Np\in\Np∈N, pick w=apbpcp∈Lw=a^pb^pc^p\in Lw=apbpcp∈L. for every partition w=xyzuvw=xyzuvw=xyzuv, we have ∣yzu∣≤p|yzu|\leq p∣yzu∣≤p (1), there exists a letter in a,b,c that does not appear in it. now pick i=2i=2i=2 and consider xy2zu2vxy^2zu^2vxy2zu2v, then apply (2) that ∣yu∣≥1|yu|\geq 1∣yu∣≥1 (it is not empty). we found that we are only increasing the count of possibly one or two letters, but not for the third letter, so the count for all three letters do not equal, failing (3). □\square□

eg. let L={ww:w∈{a,b}∗}L=\{ww:w\in\{a,b\}^*\}L={ww:w∈{a,b}∗} is not context-free (in contrast, set of palindromes are using S -> aSa|bSb|ϵ).
given any p∈Np\in\Np∈N, consider w=apbpapbp∈Lw=a^pb^pa^pb^p\in Lw=apbpapbp∈L. a division yzuyzuyzu can only touch 2 parts at most. □\square□

theorem. (closure property of CFL) if L1,L2L_1,L_2L1​,L2​ are context-free, then

  1. L1L2L_1L_2L1​L2​ is context-free
  2. L1∪L2L_1\cup L_2L1​∪L2​ is context-free
  3. L1∗L_1^*L1∗​ is context-free.

defn. LLL is a boolean combination of L1,L2L_1,L_2L1​,L2​ if there is a function ∗:{T,F}2→{T,F}*:\{T,F\}^2\rightarrow\{T,F\}∗:{T,F}2→{T,F} such that for all w∈Σ∗w\in\Sigma^*w∈Σ∗ we have w∈Lw\in Lw∈L iff ∗(w∈L1,w∈L2)=T*(w\in L_1,w\in L_2)=T∗(w∈L1​,w∈L2​)=T.

the set of CFL is however not closed under boolean operations.

eg. show L1={akbncn:n,k∈N},L2={anbnck:n,k∈N}L_1=\{a^kb^nc^n:n,k\in\N\},L_2=\{a^nb^nc^k:n,k\in\N\}L1​={akbncn:n,k∈N},L2​={anbnck:n,k∈N} are CFL, but their intersection is not.
the rules for L1L_1L1​ is:

S -> AB | ϵ
A -> Aa | ϵ
B -> bBc | ϵ

for L2L_2L2​ it is similar. we have L1∩L2={anbncn:n∈N}L_1\cap L_2=\{a^nb^nc^n:n\in\N\}L1​∩L2​={anbncn:n∈N} which is not context-free. □\square□

we also know the complement of a CFL can also be not closed because complement can be represented by union/intersection and negations.

pushdown automata

we use pushdown automata to compute CFL. it is an NFA endowed with a stack memory. whenever we scan a new letter, we can compare it with the top elements on the stack, and push it to the stack.

Week 7. Feb 14

defn. a pushdown automata is a tuple P=(Σ,Q,q0,F,δ,Γ)P=(\Sigma,Q,q_0,F,\delta,\Gamma)P=(Σ,Q,q0​,F,δ,Γ) where

  • Σ\SigmaΣ is vocabulary
  • QQQ is set of states
  • q0∈Qq_0\in Qq0​∈Q is start state
  • F⊆QF\subseteq QF⊆Q is accepting states
  • δ:(Σ∪{ϵ})×Q×(Γ∪{ϵ})→P(Q×(Γ∪{ϵ}))\delta:(\Sigma\cup\{\epsilon\})\times Q\times (\Gamma\cup\{\epsilon\})\rightarrow \mathcal{P}(Q\times(\Gamma\cup\{\epsilon\}))δ:(Σ∪{ϵ})×Q×(Γ∪{ϵ})→P(Q×(Γ∪{ϵ})) is transition function, which changes state and changes stack symbol
    • to push in γ\gammaγ, (a,q,ϵ)↦(q′,γ),...(a,q,\epsilon)\mapsto (q',\gamma),...(a,q,ϵ)↦(q′,γ),... (pretend we have an ϵ\epsilonϵ on top of stack, replacing this virtual element with γ\gammaγ is addition)
    • to delete from stack, (a,q,γ)↦(q′,ϵ),...(a,q,\gamma)\mapsto(q',\epsilon),...(a,q,γ)↦(q′,ϵ),...
  • Γ\GammaΓ is a stack symbols

defn. a word www is accepted by PPP, ie w∈L(P)w\in L(P)w∈L(P) iff there exist w0w1...wm∈(Σ∪{ϵ})∗w_0w_1...w_m\in(\Sigma\cup\{\epsilon\})^*w0​w1​...wm​∈(Σ∪{ϵ})∗, r0r1...rm∈Qr_0r_1...r_m\in Qr0​r1​...rm​∈Q, s0s1...sm∈(Γ∪{ϵ})∗s_0s_1...s_m\in(\Gamma\cup\{\epsilon\})^*s0​s1​...sm​∈(Γ∪{ϵ})∗ (ie some live contents of letter, state and stack) such that for all iii we have (ri+1,b)∈δ(ri,wi,a)(r_{i+1},b)\in\delta(r_i,w_i,a)(ri+1​,b)∈δ(ri​,wi​,a) such that si=ats_i=atsi​=at (curr stack) and si+1=bts_{i+1}=btsi+1​=bt (new stack) for t∈Γ∗t\in\Gamma^*t∈Γ∗ (sequence of stack contents), and last state rm∈Fr_m\in Frm​∈F.

we can use a 3d matrix to represent the transition function...

eg. construct a PDA accepting language L={anbn:n∈N}L=\{a^nb^n:n\in\N\}L={anbn:n∈N}.
whenever we see aaa, we push a symbol, when we see bbb, we pop a symbol. if we reach the bottom when we finish the word, we accept it.

let P=(Σ={a,b},Q={q0,q1,q2,q3},q0,F={q0,q3},δ,Γ={$,a})P=(\Sigma=\{a,b\},Q=\{q_0,q_1,q_2,q_3\}, q_0, F=\{q_0,q_3\}, \delta, \Gamma=\{\$,a\})P=(Σ={a,b},Q={q0​,q1​,q2​,q3​},q0​,F={q0​,q3​},δ,Γ={$,a}), where the transition is

corollary. if LLL is a CFL and L′L'L′ is regular, then L∩L′L\cap L'L∩L′ is a CFL.
proof. let PPP be a PDA for LLL, and DDD be a DFA for L′L'L′. define a new PDA such that it is a product of PPP and DDD:

  • Q=P×DQ=P\times DQ=P×D
  • q0=(q0P,q0D)q_0=(q_{0P},q_{0D})q0​=(q0P​,q0D​)
  • F={(q,q′):q∈FP,q′∈FD}F=\{(q,q'):q\in F_P,q'\in F_D\}F={(q,q′):q∈FP​,q′∈FD​}
  • δ(a,(q,q′),t)={(k,δD(a,q′)),t):(k,t)∈δP(a,q,t)}\delta(a,(q,q'),t)=\{(k,\delta_D(a,q')),t):(k,t)\in\delta_P(a,q,t)\}δ(a,(q,q′),t)={(k,δD​(a,q′)),t):(k,t)∈δP​(a,q,t)} □\square□

eg. given LLL is CFL and RRR is regular, is L−RL-RL−R a CFL?
note L−R=L∩R‾L-R=L\cap\overline{R}L−R=L∩R, so it is CFL. □\square□

eg. show L={w∈{a,b,c}∗:#a(w)=#b(w)=#c(w)}L=\{w\in\{a,b,c\}^*:\#_a(w)=\#_b(w)=\#c(w)\}L={w∈{a,b,c}∗:#a​(w)=#b​(w)=#c(w)} is not context-free.

turing machines

church thesis: all reasonable ways of defining what are computable tasks, are equivalent.

eg.

  • those can be computed using turing machines.
  • set of functions I(functions,{+,−,×,...},{f,g↦f∘g})I(\text{functions},\{+,-,\times,...\},\{f,g\mapsto f\circ g\})I(functions,{+,−,×,...},{f,g↦f∘g})
  • the set of all predicate functions (eg ⊢∀x...\vdash\forall x...⊢∀x...)
  • any tasks solvable by a computer program (independent of the programming language or hardware)

defn. a turing machine is a tuple T=(Σ,Γ,Q,q0,qacc,qrej,δ)T=(\Sigma,\Gamma,Q,q_0,q_\text{acc},q_\text{rej},\delta)T=(Σ,Γ,Q,q0​,qacc​,qrej​,δ) where

  • Σ\SigmaΣ: finite vocabulary
  • Γ\GammaΓ: finite symbols that can be used in the tape
  • QQQ: finite states
  • q0q_0q0​: initial state
  • qaccq_\text{acc}qacc​: accepting state
  • qrejq_\text{rej}qrej​: rejecting state
  • δ:Q×Γ→Q×Γ×{L,R}\delta:Q\times\Gamma\rightarrow Q\times\Gamma\times\{L,R\}δ:Q×Γ→Q×Γ×{L,R}
    • (q,γ)↦(q′,γ′,R)(q,\gamma)\mapsto(q',\gamma',R)(q,γ)↦(q′,γ′,R) means when the head is symbol γ\gammaγ on tape and machine is in state qqq, move the head right one location and replace symbol with γ′\gamma'γ′ and move to state q′q'q′

defn. a configuration of a turing machine is C=(u,q,v)C=(u,q,v)C=(u,q,v) where uuu is the tape locations before the current location, uuu is the locations after the current location, qqq is the current state.

_________|a|_______
<---u--->  <--v--->

defn. C→∗C′C\overset{*}{\to} C'C→∗C′ if allows going from CCC to C′C'C′ in finitely many steps.

eg. (uaqbv)→(uacq′v)(uaqbv)\to(uacq'v)(uaqbv)→(uacq′v) means δ(q,b)=(q′,c,R)\delta(q,b)=(q',c,R)δ(q,b)=(q′,c,R); (uaqbr)→(uq′acv)(uaqbr)\to(uq'acv)(uaqbr)→(uq′acv) means δ(q,b)=(q′,c,L)\delta(q,b)=(q',c,L)δ(q,b)=(q′,c,L).

defn. a word w∈Σ∗w\in\Sigma^*w∈Σ∗ is accepted by TTT, ie w∈L(T)w\in L(T)w∈L(T) iff there exist some u,v∈Γ∗u,v\in\Gamma^*u,v∈Γ∗, such that (ϵq0w)→∗(uqaccv)(\epsilon q_0w)\overset{*}{\to}(uq_\text{acc}v)(ϵq0​w)→∗(uqacc​v).

  • it is not in L(T)L(T)L(T) if either it leads to rejecting states (no configuration leading to accepting) or it leads to indefinite moving.

defn. a language LLL is turing recognizable if there exists some turing machine TTT such that L=L(T)L=L(T)L=L(T).

defn. a language is decidable if there exists a turing machine for it and the machine gets to either accepting or rejecting states.

eg. fix some first order logic, let L={α: ⊢α}L=\{\alpha:~\vdash\alpha\}L={α: ⊢α} (any proof that proves α\alphaα). it is recognizable as TTT will go over all finite sequence of formulas, for each it will 1) check whether it is legal proof 2) is the last formula α\alphaα. it is not decidable however.

  • consistent language not decidable...
              countable      uncountable
decidable ⊆ recognizable ⊆ unrecognizable

note

  • the family of decidable languages is closed under complement (just switch qacc,qrejq_\text{acc},q_\text{rej}qacc​,qrej​).
  • however turing recognizable languages are not closed under complement (those that never halt)

robustness of TM model of computation

we can consider some variations of turing machines that are equivalent.

eg. allowing the reading head not move left or right: Q×Γ→Q×Γ×{L,R,S}Q\times\Gamma\rightarrow Q\times\Gamma\times\{L,R,S\}Q×Γ→Q×Γ×{L,R,S}.
can be simulated by a standard TM: go left then back right without changing state

eg. have kkk tapes simultaneously: δ:Q×Γk→Q×Γk×{L,R}k\delta:Q\times\Gamma^k\rightarrow Q\times\Gamma^k\times\{L,R\}^kδ:Q×Γk→Q×Γk×{L,R}k.
clearly the k-tape machine is as powerful as a standard TM. create a tape that has kkk segments, and for each of them duplicate the γi\gamma_iγi​'s. each has a special letter γ‾j\overline{\gamma}_jγ​j​ where jjj's are different across segments.

-----+----------------------+-----
-----+----------------------+-----
 tape 1      ...             tape k

eg. two-stack PDA.
one stack for left side, one for right side. moving head to right => moving top element from right stack to left stack, ...

eg. non-deterministic turing machines: δ:Q×Γ→P(Q×Γ×{L,R})\delta:Q\times\Gamma\rightarrow\mathcal{P}(Q\times\Gamma\times\{L,R\})δ:Q×Γ→P(Q×Γ×{L,R}). a word www is accepted by it iff there is a way to get (uqaccv)(uq_\text{acc}v)(uqacc​v) from (q0w)(q_0w)(q0​w).
use a 3-tape TM to simulate it. start from C0=(q0w)C_0=(q_0w)C0​=(q0​w), we can go to three configurations C11,C12,C13C_{11},C_{12},C_{13}C11​,C12​,C13​, which can each have three configurations... using BFS, if there is a way to get to accepting state, then it is accepted. for the 3 tapes

  • first tape contain the input www
  • second tape pick some determinism to some computation mode
    • just a temp memory to do computation
  • third tape list nodes that have been covered. it keeps track which computation we are doing now

numerating machines

add a new state qprintq_\text{print}qprint​. when the machine reaches qprintq_\text{print}qprint​, we view the current content of the tape as the output.

defn. a word www is accepted by the enumerator EEE, ie w∈L(E)w\in L(E)w∈L(E), iff it can be printed.

defn. LLL is recursively enumerable if there exists some enumerator EEE such that L=L(E)L=L(E)L=L(E).

claim. LLL is recursively enumerable iff it is recognizable.
proof.

  • given a turing machine TTT that recognizes LLL, define a enumerator such that
    • we have two tapes. first tape is for storing contents so fat, second tape is like TTT. let w0w1...wn..w_0w_1...w_n..w0​w1​...wn​.. be a word at step iii, run TTT on w0w1...wiw_0w_1...w_iw0​w1​...wi​ for iii many steps, write them on the first step and repeat. note if w∈L(T)w\in L(T)w∈L(T) reaches its qaccq_\text{acc}qacc​. if w∈L(T)w\in L(T)w∈L(T) then it reaches qaccq_\text{acc}qacc​ and so at qprintq_\text{print}qprint​ it is printed. if w∉L(T)w\notin L(T)w∈/L(T) then either runs forever or reaches qrejq_\text{rej}qrej​.
  • given an enumerator EEE that accepts LLL, construct a turing machine where we just compare the word with what would have been printed by EEE, accept if there is a match. □\square□

theorem. a language LLL is decidable iff both LLL and Σ∗−L\Sigma^*-LΣ∗−L are recursively enumerable.
proof.

  • suppose LLL is decidable, then it is recognizable so is its complement, so they are recursively enumerable.
  • suppose L,L‾L,\overline{L}L,L are RE. let E,E‾E,\overline{E}E,E be their enumerators. define a turing machine that accepts LLL and halts on every input: for any input w∈Σ∗w\in\Sigma^*w∈Σ∗, run E,E‾E,\overline{E}E,E in parallel, we know www must be eventually printed by one of them in finite steps. □\square□

remark. language is decidable if enumerator can print strings in lexicographical order.

how can one show a language is not decidable?

hilbert's 10th problem: given a polynomial of several variables P(x,y,z,...)=0P(x,y,z,...)=0P(x,y,z,...)=0 decide if it has integer solutions.

  • if there is one variable P(x)=a0+a1x+...+akxkP(x)=a_0+a_1x+...+a_kx^kP(x)=a0​+a1​x+...+ak​xk we can calculate a bound on the absolute values of any potential solution. it is decidable.

theorem. Lp={⟨P⟩:P is a polynomial with integer solution}L_p=\{\lang P\rang:P\text{ is a polynomial with integer solution}\}Lp​={⟨P⟩:P is a polynomial with integer solution} is undecidable. (angle bracket: encode object as a binary string)

eg. {⟨G⟩:G is undirected graph that is connected}\{\lang G\rang:G\text{ is undirected graph that is connected}\}{⟨G⟩:G is undirected graph that is connected} is decidable.
try design a TM to scan the encoded string..

eg. LDFA={⟨w,D⟩:D is DFA that accepts w}L_\text{DFA}=\{\lang w,D\rang:D\text{ is DFA that accepts }w\}LDFA​={⟨w,D⟩:D is DFA that accepts w} is decidable.
just run the DFA with w...

eg. EDFA={⟨D⟩:D is DFA and L(D)=∅}E_\text{DFA}=\{\lang D\rang:D\text{ is DFA and }L(D)=\varnothing\}EDFA​={⟨D⟩:D is DFA and L(D)=∅} is decidable.

note L(D)=L(D′)L(D)=L(D')L(D)=L(D′) iff both L(D)−L(D′)L(D)-L(D')L(D)−L(D′) and L(D′)−L(D)L(D')-L(D)L(D′)−L(D) are empty. construct the difference DFA (product DFA) and go to the previous eg.

eg. ATM={⟨T,w⟩:w∈L(T)}A_{\text{TM}}=\{\lang T,w\rang:w\in L(T)\}ATM​={⟨T,w⟩:w∈L(T)} is undecidable.
assume for a contradiction that it is decidable and let AAA be the turing machine/algorithm. define a new algorithm DDD as follows:

  • fix www, on any input ⟨M⟩\lang M\rang⟨M⟩ that encodes a turing machine, and D(⟨M⟩)=acceptD(\lang M\rang)=\text{accept}D(⟨M⟩)=accept iff A(⟨M⟩,w)=rejectA(\lang M\rang,w)=\text{reject}A(⟨M⟩,w)=reject.

then feed ⟨D⟩\lang D\rang⟨D⟩ into DDD. if D(⟨D⟩)=acceptD(\lang D\rang)=\text{accept}D(⟨D⟩)=accept, then A(⟨D⟩,w)=rejectA(\lang D\rang,w)=\text{reject}A(⟨D⟩,w)=reject, then it means D(⟨D⟩)=acceptD(\lang D\rang)=\text{accept}D(⟨D⟩)=accept. same for the other direction. so we get contradiction. □\square□

however it is recognizable. given word of and the machine, just run it.

the problem for rejecting a word is it can possibly run forever.

eg. (halting problem) H={⟨M,w⟩:M halts on input w}H=\{\lang M,w\rang:M\text{ halts on input }w\}H={⟨M,w⟩:M halts on input w} is undecidable.

  • if MMM ever accepts a word xxx, compare with www and if equal, accept, otherwise reject.

feed M′M'M′ into ETMETMETM, as it runs in finitely many steps we can solve ATMA_{\text{TM}}ATM​ problem. □\square□

eg. EQTM={⟨M,M′⟩:L(M)=L(M′)}\text{EQ}_\text{TM}=\{\lang M,M'\rang:L(M)=L(M')\}EQTM​={⟨M,M′⟩:L(M)=L(M′)} is undecidable.

examples of undecidable problems that do not mention turing machines

  • existence of integer solutions of polynomial

word complexity

how to measure complexity of a words? try do this by its 'description length', ie how long is the shortest way to describe the word.

the Barry paradox: consider a number has a short definition if there is an English sentence of words less than 200 characters that defines it. is the set of all shortly described numbers finite?

  • say we have 40 chars in English. then there are 4020040^{200}40200 possible descriptions so the set is infinite.
  • then 'the smallest number that cannot be described in 4020040^{200}40200 letters'.

the problem is the description must be some fixed 'description language'.

eg. a Python program that given empty inputs it returns a string. then the program is the description.

defn. kolmogorov complexity is the length of the shortest description Kd(s):=min⁡{∣p∣:d(p)=s}K_d(s):=\min\{|p|:d(p)=s\}Kd​(s):=min{∣p∣:d(p)=s}.

theorem. some properties:

  1. for every ddd, there exists c∈Nc\in\Nc∈N such that for all ccc we have Kd(s)≤∣s∣+cK_d(s)\leq|s|+cKd​(s)≤∣s∣+c.
    • eg. print {s}
  2. there exists description that is much shorter than the word.
    • eg. '1' repeated 2^n times (length logn)
  3. there are infinitely many string sss such that Kd(s)≥∣s∣K_d(s)\geq|s|Kd​(s)≥∣s∣.
    • proof. we ask how many descriptions of size less than ∣s∣|s|∣s∣ are there: ∑i=1∣s∣−12i=2∣s∣−1\sum_{i=1}^{|s|-1}2^i=2^{|s|}-1∑i=1∣s∣−1​2i=2∣s∣−1 (assume alphabet is binary encoded). however there are 2∣s∣2^{|s|}2∣s∣ strings of size ∣s∣|s|∣s∣, so for every length nnn, there is one string sss such that ∣s∣=n|s|=n∣s∣=n and Kd(s)≥∣s∣K_d(s)\geq|s|Kd​(s)≥∣s∣. □\square□

defn. we say string sss is b-compressible if Kd(s)≤∣s∣−bK_d(s)\leq|s|-bKd​(s)≤∣s∣−b.

claim. for every b>1b>1b>1 and for all large enough nnn, most of the string of length nnn are not b-compressible.
proof. there are at most ∑i=1∣s∣−b2i=2∣s∣−b−1\sum_{i=1}^{|s|-b}2^i=2^{|s|-b}-1∑i=1∣s∣−b​2i=2∣s∣−b−1 descriptions of size below ∣s∣−b|s|-b∣s∣−b and there are 2∣s∣2^{|s|}2∣s∣ strings of length ∣s∣|s|∣s∣. even b = 1 we cannot compress half of them. □\square□

how to say a string is random? can you use probability? no because strings have same probability to be generated

10101010101010101010  p=1/2^20
10110101000101010111  p=1/2^20

Chaitin defines a string to be 'random' if it is not compressible.

defn. a property PPP of a string is rare if lim⁡n→∞∣{s:∣s∣=n,s has P}∣2n=0\lim_{n\rightarrow\infty}\frac{|\{s:|s|=n,s\text{ has }P\}|}{2^n}=0limn→∞​2n∣{s:∣s∣=n,s has P}∣​=0.

claim. for every rare property PPP, for every bbb there exists nnn such that all strings of length nnn that satisfy PPP are b-compressible.

  • in other words, incompressible strings do not satisfy rare properties.

pf. 'the i-th string that satisfies P' is a compressed description of that string once PPP is random and iii is larger (c+log⁡ic+\log ic+logi).

theorem. some straightforward 'positive' results (upperbound of KdK_dKd​):

  1. ∀x ∃c Kd(xx)≤c+Kd(x)\forall x~\exists c~K_d(xx)\leq c+K_d(x)∀x ∃c Kd​(xx)≤c+Kd​(x)
  2. ∀x∀y ∃c Kd(xy)≤c+Kd(x)+Kd(y)+log⁡(Kd(x))\forall x\forall y~\exists c~K_d(xy)\leq c+K_d(x)+K_d(y)+\log(K_d(x))∀x∀y ∃c Kd​(xy)≤c+Kd​(x)+Kd​(y)+log(Kd​(x))
    • log: we have to know how long to express xxx
  3. for every two programming languages d,d′d,d'd,d′ and every string sss, there is some constant bd,d′b_{d,d'}bd,d′​ such that Kd(s)≤Kd′(s)+bdd′K_d(s)\leq K_{d'}(s)+b_{dd'}Kd​(s)≤Kd′​(s)+bdd′​.
    • bdd′b_{dd'}bdd′​ is length of compiler that translates ddd to d′d'd′
  4. for every pairs of strings s1,s2s_1,s_2s1​,s2​ there exist programming languages d1,d2d_1,d_2d1​,d2​ such that Kd1(s1)<<Kd2(s2)K_{d_1}(s_1)<<K_{d_2}(s_2)Kd1​​(s1​)<<Kd2​​(s2​) and vice versa.

theorem. for any given programming language ddd there is no algorithm such that for every sss it computes Kd(s)K_d(s)Kd​(s) (KdK_dKd​ is not computable).
proof. following the argument of the Barry paradox. assume there is some algo AAA that computes correctly Kd(s)K_d(s)Kd​(s) for all sss. what is the length of the a d-program computing 'the first string s of Kd(s)>LK_d(s)>LKd​(s)>L for LLL? then it is

for each string in lexicographical order:
    for each si:
        run A to find si
        return first si such that A(si) > L

then the length of this program is Kd′(s)=c+log⁡LK_d'(s)=c+\log LKd′​(s)=c+logL (L is the only variable and we need log⁡L\log LlogL bits). if LLL is sufficiently large, then we can always find some c+log⁡L<Lc+\log L<Lc+logL<L. we get contradiction.

another proof halting problem is undecidable: given program that decides HP, we could then compute Kd(s)K_d(s)Kd​(s) for every sss: by going over all programs in lexi order. given empty input, check if any program of size <∣s∣<|s|<∣s∣ outputs sss. before we run program, use HP to check whether it halts on empty input.

we know that for every length LLL there are only finitely many strings sss with Kd(s)≤LK_d(s)\leq LKd​(s)≤L. can we prove a lower bound?

theorem. for any proof system there is some L<∞L<\inftyL<∞ such that this system cannot proof Kd(s)>LK_d(s)>LKd​(s)>L for any sss.
again use Barry paradox.

Week 11. Mar 14

computable functions

defn. a function f:Σ∗→Σ∗f:\Sigma^*\rightarrow\Sigma^*f:Σ∗→Σ∗ is computable if there is a turing machine MMM such that for every w∈Σ∗w\in\Sigma^*w∈Σ∗ as input, MMM eventually halts with f(w)f(w)f(w) as its tape content.

we know recognizable and recursively enumerable are equivalent notions. it is also equivalent to LLL being the range of some computable function fff (ie L={f(n):n∈N}L=\{f(n):n\in\N\}L={f(n):n∈N}).

defn. for languages A,BA,BA,B, we say AAA is mapping reducible to BBB, denoted A≤mBA\leq_m BA≤m​B, if there is computable function f:Σ∗→Σ∗f:\Sigma^*\rightarrow\Sigma^*f:Σ∗→Σ∗ such that for every w∈Σ∗w\in\Sigma^*w∈Σ∗, w∈Aw\in Aw∈A iff f(w)∈Bf(w)\in Bf(w)∈B.

  • we do not care one-to-one or onto

theorem. if A≤mBA\leq_mBA≤m​B and BBB is decidable, then AAA is decidable.

theorem. if A≤mBA\leq_mBA≤m​B and BBB is recognizable, then AAA is recognizable.

we know already recognizable language does not imply complement is recognizable. but can there be language such that itself and its complement are both not recognizable?

claim. both EQTM\text{EQ}_{\text{TM}}EQTM​ and EQTM‾\overline{\text{EQ}_{\text{TM}}}EQTM​​ are not recognizable.
proof.

logic

first order logic:

  • syntax
    • the language
    • vocabulary
    • symbols (,),∧,→,∨,¬,∀,∃(,),\land,\rightarrow,\lor,\lnot,\forall,\exist(,),∧,→,∨,¬,∀,∃ and variables
    • language-specific symbols: constant symbols, relation symbols, function symbols
    • proof system and ⊢\vdash⊢
    • assume equality always exists
  • sematics
    • 'meaning' of language
    • structure/model/interpretation M=(universe set, set of interpretations of relation and function symbols)
    • theorems and ⊨\vDash⊨
  • terms: if ttt is a term and fff is function symbol then f(t)f(t)f(t) is a term
  • atomic formulas: apply relation symbols to terms
  • general formulas

eg. for M=(N,{a,∗,+,<})M=(\N,\{a,*,+,<\})M=(N,{a,∗,+,<}), we have language L={...,a,g(,),f(,),R(,)}L=\{...,a,g(,),f(,),R(,)\}L={...,a,g(,),f(,),R(,)} to represent the relations and functions. we can use these to write formulas eg ∀x∃y(R(x,y)∧∀s∀t(g(s,t)=y  ⟹  s=y∨t=y))\forall x\exist y(R(x,y)\land\forall s\forall t(g(s,t)=y\implies s=y\lor t=y))∀x∃y(R(x,y)∧∀s∀t(g(s,t)=y⟹s=y∨t=y)) ('there are infinitely many primes').

defn. a formula is called a sentence if all of its variables are quantifiers.

  • it is either true or false
  • while formulas have unassigned free variables, we do not know whether it is true or false yet since we do not know its meaning

defn. given structure MMM, its theorems is Th(M)={x:M⊨x}\text{Th}(M)=\{x:M\vDash x\}Th(M)={x:M⊨x} (true sentences).

theorem. for a language LLL and structure MMM for that language, then for every sentence xxx in the language, then either x∈Th(M)x\in\text{Th}(M)x∈Th(M) or x∉Th(M)x\notin\text{Th}(M)x∈/Th(M).

defn. a proof system PPP is set of rules that defines which formula a 'formal theorem' is provable (⊢Pα\vdash_P\alpha⊢P​α), ie satisfying.

  1. there is a certificate 'proof' in the proof system and the set of all legal proofs is decidable;
  2. sound: for some structure MMM, for all α\alphaα we have ⊢Pα  ⟹  M⊨α\vdash_P\alpha\implies M\vDash\alpha⊢P​α⟹M⊨α

proof. go over all strings in lexi order and given string www apply the proof system decider to check whether www is legal proof in LLL, if so, print out what www proves.

we know the set {α:N⊨α}\{\alpha:\N\vDash\alpha\}{α:N⊨α} is 'complete' in the sense that either for every α\alphaα, either α∈Th(N)\alpha\in\text{Th}(\N)α∈Th(N) or ¬α∈Th(N)\lnot\alpha\in\text{Th}(\N)¬α∈Th(N). it is recursively enumerable but not decidable.

how to define natural numbers? we cannot prove anything but we can try focusing on natural numbers only. Peano arithmetic is an accepted proof system for N\NN.

ZFC (Zermelo-Fraenkel set theory) can prove every axiom of PA.

if ϕ(x,y)\phi(x,y)ϕ(x,y) denotes a function over N\NN, then we need

  • ∀x∀y∀y′:ϕ(x,y)∧ϕ(x,y′)  ⟹  y=y′\forall x\forall y\forall y':\phi(x,y)\land\phi(x,y')\implies y=y'∀x∀y∀y′:ϕ(x,y)∧ϕ(x,y′)⟹y=y′
  • ∀x∃y:ϕ(x,y)\forall x\exist y:\phi(x,y)∀x∃y:ϕ(x,y)

a function is computable iff it can be expressed by a formula ppp such that PA⊢two properties\text{PA}\vdash\text{two properties}PA⊢two properties.

as corollary, there exist functions such that ZFC can prove both properties but they grow faster than any computable function (can cannot be proved by PA).

example of ZFC is not complete:

eg. (continuous hypothesis) ZFC cannot prove the statement "∣R∣=ℵ0|\R|=\alef_0∣R∣=ℵ0​" nor its negation.

eg. (Goldel's 2nd incompleteness) for any consistent proof system PPP, P⊬Cons(P)P\not\vdash\text{Cons}(P)P⊢Cons(P) ie PPP cannot prove PPP is consistent.

however ZFC⊢Cons(PA)\text{ZFC}\vdash\text{Cons}(\text{PA})ZFC⊢Cons(PA).

complexity

once a language/problem is computable, now we can consider its time complexity and space complexity.

defn. for functions f,g:N→Nf,g:\N\rightarrow\Nf,g:N→N, we say f(n)=O(g(n))f(n)=O(g(n))f(n)=O(g(n)) if there exists some c∈Nc\in\Nc∈N such that for all n>n0n>n_0n>n0​ such that f(n)<cg(n)f(n)<cg(n)f(n)<cg(n).

  • f(n)=O(g(n))f(n)=O(g(n))f(n)=O(g(n)) if lim⁡n→∞f(n)g(n)=0\lim_{n\rightarrow\infty}\frac{f(n)}{g(n)}=0limn→∞​g(n)f(n)​=0.

defn. the time complexity up to a polynomial of a problem is the time it takes for the most efficient algorithm.

eg. find the time complexity of {akbk:k∈N}⊂{a,b}∗\{a^kb^k:k\in\N\}\subset\{a,b\}^*{akbk:k∈N}⊂{a,b}∗. given string of length nnn. after checking aaa's are followed by bbb's, given a one-tape machine we can do

  • algo1: delete leftmost aaa, then move cursor and delete rightmost bbb, repeat. then this will take O(n2)O(n^2)O(n2) steps
  • algo2: go from left to right, delete every second aaa and every second bbb, go back and repeat. then this will take O(nlog⁡n)O(n\log n)O(nlogn) steps

if we have two-tape machine

  • algo3: move all aaa's from first tape to second tape, then run both taps to check if numbers are equal. O(n)O(n)O(n) steps.

refined church thesis: for every problem and evert two 'reasonable' models of computation, the time complexity of solving the problem on those machines is within a polynomial of each other.

eg. for every problem solvable in any time f(n)f(n)f(n) by a two-tape machine, the problem can be solved by a 1-tape machine in time O(f(n)2)O(f(n)^2)O(f(n)2).
for the 1-tape machine, put a barrier so that it has two parts corresponding to the 2 tapes. if on the 2-tape machine we cross the tapes at most f(n)f(n)f(n) times, then the 1-tape machine has to move O(f(n)2)O(f(n)^2)O(f(n)2) times to account for this. □\square□

defn. the class P is the family of all problems solvable in polynomial time (in terms of input size nnn).

P=⋃k∈NT(nk)P=\bigcup_{k\in\N}T(n^k) P=k∈N⋃​T(nk)

the class P is commonly accepted as modeling 'feasible problems'.

issues of this interpretation:

  • is n10000n^{10000}n10000 feasible? 'the exponent is fixed for all input sizes.'
  • only asymptotic
  • there is worst-cast condition

eg. for problems over graphs, we represent a graph by its adjacency matrix MGM_GMG​. then the size of this representation ∣⟨G⟩∣≈∣V∣2|\lang G\rang|\approx|V|^2∣⟨G⟩∣≈∣V∣2. we also know MGM_GMG​ is symmetric iff GGG is undirected.

eg. for the problem Lp={n:n is prime}L_p=\{n:n\text{ is prime}\}Lp​={n:n is prime}. we represent number by its binary representation ∣⟨n⟩∣≈log⁡n|\lang n\rang|\approx\log n∣⟨n⟩∣≈logn. can we solve this in polynomial time?

  • algo1: given input nnn, for all i≤ni\leq\sqrt{n}i≤n​ we compute ni\frac{n}{i}in​, accept if no division if without a remainder. the run time is roughly O(n)O(\sqrt{n})O(n​) but the nnn is the number we check (not representation). the real run time is O(2∣⟨n⟩∣)O(\sqrt{2^{|\lang n\rang|}})O(2∣⟨n⟩∣​), so it is not a poly algo.

defn. a language LLL belongs to NP if there exists a polynomial time (in the size of www) deciding (verification) algorithm VVV such that L={w:∃c V(w,c)=accept}L=\{w:\exist c ~V(w,c)=\text{accept}\}L={w:∃c V(w,c)=accept}.

defn. CoNP={L:L‾∈NP}\text{CoNP}=\{L:\overline{L}\in NP\}CoNP={L:L∈NP}.

eg. SAT={φ:φ is a satisfiable formula in propositional logic}SAT=\{\varphi:\varphi\text{ is a satisfiable formula in propositional logic}\}SAT={φ:φ is a satisfiable formula in propositional logic}. formula is satisfiable if there exists a truth assignment such that formula gets true.

  • such a truth assignment is a certificate and the verification is done in poly time.
  • but SAT‾\overline{SAT}SAT does not have an easy certificate..
  • similarly TUAT={φ:φ is a tautology}TUAT=\{\varphi:\varphi\text{ is a tautology}\}TUAT={φ:φ is a tautology} it is not clear if it is NP..

why is this class called NP?

defn. an algorithm/turing machine is nondeterministic if at every step it may have more than one next step configurations. such algorithm is polynomial time nondeterministic if no matter which choices are picked, the run ends in some polynomial time.

defn. a language LLL is accepted by a nondeterministic turing machine iff at least one of the possible paths of the TM ends in accept state.

theorem. a language LLL is in NP iff it can be decided by a nondeterministic polynomial time algorithm.

  • assume LLL is accepted by such a TM. for every w∈Lw\in Lw∈L, let the certificate be the choice that the sequence of next step choices made by the TM that leads an accept state. then we can run this sequence in TM in poly time
  • assume for some verifier VVV and L={w:∃c V(w,c)=accept}L=\{w:\exist c~V(w,c)=\text{accept}\}L={w:∃c V(w,c)=accept}. the nondeterministic TM for it will go over all binary ccc's of length ≤O(nk)\leq O(n^{k})≤O(nk), the upper bound on the runtime of VVV, and use VVV. then one of them ends in poly time. □\square□

remark. P⊆NP⊆⋃k∈NUT(2nk)P\subseteq NP\subseteq\bigcup_{k\in\N}UT(2^{n^k})P⊆NP⊆⋃k∈N​UT(2nk).

it is not clear whether P=NPP=NPP=NP.

claim. for every RE language LLL, there is a decidable language L′L'L′ such that L={w:∃v (w,v)∈L′}L=\{w:\exists v~(w,v)\in L'\}L={w:∃v (w,v)∈L′}

  • by this we can also get L‾={w:∀v (w,v)∈L′‾}\overline{L}=\{w:\forall v~(w,v)\in\overline{L'}\}L={w:∀v (w,v)∈L′}

we can generate more complex languages based on LLL by using this 'projection' operation.

  • or by complementation of a projection

poly time hierarchy each step we get something new

  • we change exists to for all then to exists ..., language will be more and more complex (logical complexity)

we do not know whether the intersection of all this hierarchy is PPP.

defn. we say AAA is reducible to BBB, A≤mCBA\leq_m^C BA≤mC​B if there is a reduction f:A→Bf:A\rightarrow Bf:A→B within the resources class CCC.

defn. a 3-SAT variable is any propositional variable, a 3-SAT literal is any variable or its negation, a 3-SAT clause is ∧,∨\land,\lor∧,∨ of 3-SAT literals, a CNF (conjunctive normal form) formula has clauses that have ∨,¬\lor,\lnot∨,¬, and clauses are joined using ∧\land∧.

  • every propositional formula is equivalent to a CNF formula

in fact for every boolean function f:1,0n→{0,1}f:{1,0}^n\rightarrow\{0,1\}f:1,0n→{0,1} there exists a CNF formula such that the truth table of fff equals the truth table of that formula.

  • whenever we see a row like 1001→11001 \rightarrow11001→1, we construct p1∧¬p2∧¬p3∧p4p_1\land \lnot p_2\land\lnot p_3\land p_4p1​∧¬p2​∧¬p3​∧p4​, use de morgan's law to convert to CNF
  • finally use ∨\lor∨ to join all rows

3-SAT: the set of all CNF formulas in which every clause has 3 literals.

claim. CNF−SAT≤mp3SATCNF-SAT\leq_m^p 3SATCNF−SAT≤mp​3SAT.
split clause into pieces, eg p1∨p2∨p3∨p4≡(p1∨p2∨p3)∧(¬p1∨p3∨p4)p_1\lor p_2\lor p_3\lor p_4\equiv(p_1\lor p_2\lor p_3)\land(\lnot p_1\lor p_3\lor p_4)p1​∨p2​∨p3​∨p4​≡(p1​∨p2​∨p3​)∧(¬p1​∨p3​∨p4​).

claim. 3SAT≤mPK-Clique3SAT\leq_m^P \text{K-Clique}3SAT≤mP​K-Clique.
proof. given φ=C1∩C2∩...∩Ck=(l11∨l12∨l12)∧...∧(lk1∨lk2∨lk2)\varphi=C_1\cap C_2\cap...\cap C_k=(l_{11}\lor l_{12}\lor l_{12})\land...\land(l_{k1}\lor l_{k2}\lor l_{k2})φ=C1​∩C2​∩...∩Ck​=(l11​∨l12​∨l12​)∧...∧(lk1​∨lk2​∨lk2​) as input of 3SAT. for each clause, spawn 3 vertices. we connect every pair of vertices by an edge except if either the pair belongs to the same triplet, or labeled with contradictory literals. then if φ\varphiφ is satisfiable iff GGG has a k-clique. □\square□

defn. a language LLL is NP-hard if SAT≤mPLSAT\leq_m^P LSAT≤mP​L.

defn. LLL is NP-complete if L∈NPL\in NPL∈NP and for all V∈NPV\in NPV∈NP, V≤mPV\leq_m^PV≤mP​ to LLL.

  • in other words, it is NP and NP-hard.

theorem. (cook-levin) for every LLL in NPNPNP, L≤mPSATL\leq_m^PSATL≤mP​SAT, ie SATSATSAT is NP-complete.

  • even 3SAT3SAT3SAT is NP-complete

corollary. K-Clique\text{K-Clique}K-Clique is NP-complete.

corollary. if SATSATSAT can be solved by poly time, then so can any problem in NPNPNP.

corollary. for every LLL such that SAT≤mPLSAT\leq_m^P LSAT≤mP​L, if LLL is solvable in poly time, then so is every problem in NPNPNP.

after this theorem, we know P=NP  ⟺  3SAT∈PP=NP\iff 3SAT\in PP=NP⟺3SAT∈P (or any other NPC problem).

many practical problems can be cast as instances of SAT (hardware verification).

there are lots of SAT solvers.

outline of proof for cook-levin: given an NP language LLL, we want to find a poly time reduction fff such that w∈Lw\in Lw∈L iff f(w)f(w)f(w) is satisfiable formula. we know there is some non-deterministic TM M={Σ,Γ,Q,q0,qacc,δ}M=\{\Sigma,\Gamma,Q,q_0,q_{\text{acc}},\delta\}M={Σ,Γ,Q,q0​,qacc​,δ} with w∈Lw\in Lw∈L iff some computation of MMM that starts with input www and ends in qaccq_\text{acc}qacc​. let kkk be such that each run of MMM on www consists of at most ∣w∣k|w|^k∣w∣k steps.

we now construct a prop formula φM,w\varphi_{M,w}φM,w​ that encodes a run of MMM on www.

the number of cols is roughly ∣w∣k|w|^k∣w∣k. we want our formula to express the following:

  • φ1=first row is #q0w1...wn...#\varphi_1=\text{first row is }\#q_0w_1...w_n...\#φ1​=first row is #q0​w1​...wn​...#
  • φ2\varphi_2φ2​ = every entry in the matrix is either in Γ\GammaΓ or in QQQ
  • φ3\varphi_3φ3​ = in every raw exactly one entry is in QQQ
  • φ4\varphi_4φ4​ = in one of rows we have qaccq_\text{acc}qacc​
  • φ5\varphi_5φ5​ = every row is a δ\deltaδ move from the row above it

for each i,j≤nk,s∈γ∪Qi,j\leq n^k,s\in\gamma\cup Qi,j≤nk,s∈γ∪Q, we will have a prop variable pijsp_{ijs}pijs​. we give this variable true iff sss is the content of the (i,j)(i,j)(i,j) entry of the matrix. then the first row can be described by:

p11#∧p12q0∧...∧pijwj−2p_{11\#}\land p_{12q_0}\land...\land p_{ijw_{j-2}} p11#​∧p12q0​​∧...∧pijwj−2​​

and more...

⋁i,j;q∈Qpijq,⋁i,j;r∈Γpijr,⋀i;j≠j′;q,q′∈Qpijq→pij′q′\bigvee_{i,j;q\in Q}p_{ijq}, \bigvee_{i,j;r\in \Gamma}p_{ijr}, \bigwedge_{i; j\neq j';q,q'\in Q}p_{ijq}\rightarrow p_{ij'q'} i,j;q∈Q⋁​pijq​,i,j;r∈Γ⋁​pijr​,i;j=j′;q,q′∈Q⋀​pijq​→pij′q′​

and continue in this fashion we will get a formula satisfiable iff we have a valid run on the input.

are there languages LLL such that L∈NPL\in NPL∈NP and L∉PL\notin PL∈/P? if all L∈NPL\in NPL∈NP except empty and universe is NPCNPCNPC then P=NPP=NPP=NP.

eg. we say a graph G=(V,E)G=(V,E)G=(V,E) has a k-size vertex cover if there is some W⊆V,∣W∣=kW\subseteq V,|W|=kW⊆V,∣W∣=k such that every e∈Ee\in Ee∈E contains one vertex in WWW. let LVC={⟨G,k⟩:G has vertex cover of size k}L_{VC}=\{\lang G,k\rang:G\text{ has vertex cover of size }k\}LVC​={⟨G,k⟩:G has vertex cover of size k}. then it is NP-complete.
it suffices to show 3SAT≤mPLVC3SAT\leq_m^P L_{VC}3SAT≤mP​LVC​. given 3SAT formula φ\varphiφ, construct a graph GGG and a number kkk.

  • type 1 vertices: for each variable ppp in φ\varphiφ, produce an edge connecting two nodes ppp and p‾\overline{p}p​.
  • type 2 vertices: then for each clause, add three nodes corresponding to the three literals and connect them to each other within the clause gadget, and to the type 1 nodes that have same labels.

then the total number of vertices is 2m+3l2m+3l2m+3l where mmm is number of variables and lll is number of clauses. choose k=m+2lk=m+2lk=m+2l.

roughly speaking, we view problems in P as feasible (solvable in measurable time) and NP-hard problems as infeasible. the difference is not so sharp

  1. a problem can be outside P due to just very rare hard instances
  2. being in P does not yield easy solutions since the poly time exponent may be to large

consider following scenario: SAT∉PSAT\notin PSAT∈/P but there is algo that solves SATSATSAT in time ns(n)n^{s(n)}ns(n) where sss is a very slow growing function (inverse of difficult-to-compute fast growing function) and we cannot notice the difference. still cannot prove.

aside

oracle computation: endow a turing machine with the ability to query some 'oracle language' LLL. the MLM^LML machine has a new query tape, and when it writes some www on that tape, it gets bit 1 iff w∈Lw\in Lw∈L.

  • eg: CoNP∈PNPCoNP\in P^{NP}CoNP∈PNP. given any www, write copy www to the oracle tape of SATSATSAT and get the answer. this is poly time machine that computes Σ∗−SAT\Sigma^*-SATΣ∗−SAT.
  • solavary-gill proved that there exist languages A,BA,BA,B such that PA=NPA,PB≠NPBP^A=NP^A,P^B\neq NP^BPA=NPA,PB=NPB
  • as corollary, no diagonalization argument can resolve the P vs. NP question.
